Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  Entering old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled is only permitted under certain conditions:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show proof of 2G+ (approval no older than 72 hours)  â¢	If it can be credibly demonstrated that a negative PCR test cannot be presented for reasons of lack of availability, an untimely evaluation or due to the unpredictability of the official activity to be performed, operators may exceptionally admit persons even if they have 3G proof submit. This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following generally applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G+ proof.  â¢	Exceptions: Accompanying persons of underage residents: inside residential facilities for the disabled, for visitors of palliative and hospice patients, as well as pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only let employees in if they can show proof of 2.5G.  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, statutory representatives, bodies responsible for care supervision or members of established commissions.    The following applies to operators:  â¢	Operators of old peopleâs and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled may only admit new residents if they can show proof of 2.5G. If no 2.5G proof can be provided, quarantine or other suitable measures should be implemented in accordance with a Covid-19 prevention concept.  â¢	Operators of retirement and nursing homes must offer residents an antigen test or PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	Operators must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220218132709/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled    Entering residential homes for the elderly and nursing homes as well as residential homes for the disabled is only permitted under certain conditions:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G proof and also a valid PCR test (valid for 72 hours), or 2G proof and also an antigen test carried out by an authorized body (valid for 24 hours). .  â¢	If it can be credibly demonstrated that a negative PCR test cannot be presented for reasons of lack of availability, an untimely evaluation or due to the unpredictability of the official activity to be performed, operators may exceptionally admit persons even if they have 3G proof submit. This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G+ proof.  â¢	Exceptions are given for persons accompanying underage residents of inpatient residential facilities for the disabled, as well as for visits by palliative and hospice patients, for pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only let employees in if they can show proof of 2.5G.  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, statutory representatives, bodies responsible for care supervision or members of established commissions.    The following applies to operators:  â¢	Operators of stationary old people's homes and care facilities as well as stationary housing facilities for the disabled may only admit residents to new admissions if they can show proof of 2.5G. If no 2.5G proof can be provided, quarantine or other suitable measures should be implemented in accordance with a Covid-19 prevention concept.  â¢	Operators of inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly must offer residents an antigen test or PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	Operators must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/5egKM [Nationwide measures]  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221202947/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html [Coronavirus: current measures]  https://archive.vn/DibEY [5th amendment to the 4th COVID-19 Measures Ordinance]

Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  In principle, the planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested).  â¢	Exceptions are given for persons accompanying underage residents of inpatient residential facilities for the disabled, as well as for visits by palliative and hospice patients, for pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	The FFP2 mask requirement applies in closed rooms.    The following applies to residents:  â¢	For new admissions, evidence of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested) must be presented.  â¢	An FFP2 mask must be worn in closed rooms in places that are generally accessible and not part of the living area.  â¢	Residents can be offered an antigen test or PCR test by operators at least every seven days, and if they have left the home within this period, at least every three days.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only admit employees if they can show proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested).  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in direct contact with residents.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, residents' representatives, patient, disabled and nursing advocates, nursing supervisory bodies or members of established commissions.    **In Vienna**  Hospitals and nursing homes  â¢	The 2.5G rule applies to visitors in hospitals in Vienna . There is no restriction on patient visitors. An FFP2 mask must be worn for the entire duration of the visit.  â¢	The 2.5G rule and an FFP2 mask requirement also apply to hospital staff. The staff is also required to take part in a PCR screening twice a week.  â¢	The 2.5G rule applies to visitors in nursing homes in Vienna . The 2.5G rule also applies to the staff here, as well as mandatory participation in a PCR screening twice a week.    **In Carinthia**  Inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly  From January 17, 2022 (until March 31, 2022) additional measures will apply in Carinthia for inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly:    Work:  â¢	2G proof required. If such proof cannot be presented, proof of a negative PCR test that was taken no more than 48 hours ago must be presented. In exceptional cases (maintenance of operations), a negative PCR test can be presented, which must not have been taken more than 72 hours ago.  â¢	in addition, a PCR test must be carried out three times a week after starting work or entering the facility.  â¢	Special rule: "Boosted" people only need to carry out a PCR test once a week after starting work or entering the facility.  â¢	In the event of a positive test result, entry is still permitted if there are no symptoms for at least 48 hours after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on medical grounds, in particular based on a CT value of more than 30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.    Visitors:   â¢	Visitors may only be admitted if they have 2G+ proof, which must not have been issued more than 48 hours ago.  â¢	In the event of a positive test result, entry is still permitted if there are no symptoms for at least 48 hours after the infection has expired and it can be assumed on medical grounds, in particular, based on a CT value of more than 30, that there is no longer any risk of infection.    Residents:  â¢	The operator must enable the residents to carry out a PCR test once a week.  Details can be found in the relevant ordinance and the amendment .    **In Burgenland**  Hospitals with beds, social institutions and mobile care and support services  â¢	Employees, owners and operators without 2G proof must also present negative PCR test proof (not older than 48 hours) each time they start work.  â¢	Employees, owners and operators with 2G proof must also submit a negative PCR test (not older than 72 hours) twice a week.  â¢	The 2G+ proof (valid PCR test not older than 48 hours) applies to visitors to hospitals with beds, social facilities, mobile care and support services as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled.    Sources:  https://archive.ph/7RABT [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.ph/HM3ky [Coronavirus: current measures]  https://archive.ph/OoVRp [Overview of the current Corona rules - Vienna]  https://archive.ph/UdG3A [Current measures in Carinthia at a glance]  https://archive.ph/aalil [Current measures in Burgenland at a glance]

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. (Red(High risk), Yellow(Moderate risk) and Green(Low risk)). Stricter rules apply for countries considered to be Very High Risk.    Vaccinated people from ZONES catorized at "RED" outside the European Union or Schengen area are required to get tested before your arrival in Belgium (PCR or RAT), regardless of the length of stay and to get also tested (PCR) on day 1 and 7 after arrival in Belgium. They would also have to stay in quarantine until the negative result of your test on day 1.    Those coming in from a GREEN or ORANGE zone do not need to get tested or quarantine.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210045624/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. There are currently 5 colours: green, orange, red, dark red and grey.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who live a?country or zone that is not very high risk? do not need to get tested or quarantine.     - Those who live in a very high-risk country or zone?inside the European Union or Schengen Area who have a vaccination or recovery certificate do not need to quarantine or get tested. Those who do not have a vaccination or recovery certificate have to get tested (PCR) up to 72 hours before arrival. Those who test positive, must be quarantined and are not allowed to travel. OR get tested (PCR) on arrival and maintain a quarantine until the results are announced. Those who text negative can then end quarantine as soon as they get the test result.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who have been in a very high-risk country outside the EU/Schengen area in the past 14 days are ?not allowed to travel to Belgium.         Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220217212028/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. There are currently 5 colours: green, orange, red, dark red and grey.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who live a country or zone that is not very high risk do not need to get tested or quarantine.     - Those who live in a very high-risk country or zone inside the European Union or Schengen Area who have a vaccination or recovery certificate do not need to quarantine or get tested. Those who do not have a vaccination or recovery certificate have to get tested (PCR) up to 72 hours before arrival. Those who test positive, must be quarantined and are not allowed to travel. OR get tested (PCR) on arrival and maintain a quarantine until the results are announced. Those who text negative can then end quarantine as soon as they get the test result.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who have been in a very high-risk country outside the EU/Schengen area in the past 14 days are not allowed to travel to Belgium except under some circumstances which are explained here: https://web.archive.org/web/20220306174152/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/exemptions/    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220217212028/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Wearing a face mask remains mandatory for everyone in the following areas:    - on public transport from entering the indoor areas of the airport, the station, on the platform or a bus, (pre-)metro, tram, train stop or any other means of transport organised by a public authority. Public transport operators and all bus operators carrying out public transport services are not required to cover their nose and mouth, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in the indoor areas of organised collective transport (i.e. transport organised in advance with a clear itinerary or final destination and a vehicle with at least 9+1 seats (passengers + driver)), this does not apply to public transport operators, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in establishments and places where close-contact professions are carried out. This applies to service providers and customers where there is direct physical contact between the service provider and the customer or where the distance of 1.5 metres cannot be guaranteed between the service provider and the customer for a duration of at least 15 minutes;  - the publicly accessible areas of companies, associations and services;  the publicly accessible areas of commercial establishments, shops and shopping centres;  libraries, game and multimedia libraries;  - in the indoor areas accessible to the public of establishments belonging to the sports sector, including fitness centres and establishments that may remain open in accordance with Article 7, Â§1 of the Royal Decree, subject to items 11 and 12 below;  - in places of worship and buildings intended for the public practice of non-denominational moral services;  when moving around in public and non-public parts of courthouses and courtrooms and, in other cases, in accordance with the guidelines laid down by the Chairman;  - the publicly accessible areas of government buildings;  establishments and places where catering activities are permitted, both for staff and those customers who are not seated at a table or at the bar;  locations where authorised private gatherings and activities in an organised context take place with more than 50 people indoors or 100 people outdoors;  - venues for events of any size, including mass events, authorised outdoor conferences and authorised sports competitions;  trade fairs, including exhibitions;  - other locations where access is organised in accordance with the Cooperation Agreement of 14 July 2021 with regard to the CST. *the indoor areas of schools and educational institutions;  - the indoor areas of the after-school care facilities for primary school children.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220127105912/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

Suspension of group adult classes.  Face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed provided at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers.  https://archive.vn/C1xRK

Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (distance work / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of at most 50% of the staff.    Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organize the work process of the employees, as:  (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 and 10.00, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work;  (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.    Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centers, dialysis centers, hospices and nursing homes organize the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order. The employer can arrange for a COVID-19 study to be performed with rapid on-site antigen testing.  https://archive.vn/C1xRK

The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, symposiums, trainings, competitions, exams and other group events of this nature is suspended. The holding of all mass events, such as music and other festivals, fairs, folklore initiatives and others of such nature, shall be suspended.Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theaters, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances are suspended.     Indoor team sports are suspended, with the exception of trainings and competitions for registered athletes at licensed sports federations. Sports competitions are allowed without an audience. Visits to fitness centers, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centers, SPA centers, wellness centers and thalassotherapy centers are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation.     Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping center type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centers.     Exceptions apply in certain conditions where staff is vaccinated or have provided a negative COVID test result.   https://archive.vn/C1xRK

Exceptions apply in certain conditions where staff is vaccinated or have provided a negative COVID test result.    https://archive.vn/C1xRK

Public transport is operating. All persons must cover their mouth and nose with a mask or covering on all public transportation including while in railway, bus and metro stations, and airports etc.  https://archive.vn/7Sbkz
No curfew in place.   https://archive.vn/7Sbkz
No restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.   https://archive.vn/7Sbkz

Under the Bulgarian Ministry of Health order, countries are classified as Green, Orange, Red, or Dark Red Zones based on their COVID-19 risk. The current classification of countries as Green, Orange, Red, and Dark Red Zones is listed on the bg.usembassy site. No countries classify as green zone. Persons who present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has had a booster dose, or a similar document which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, do not need to present a negative PCR test result to enter the country. Bulgarian citizens and holders of permanent, long-term, or continuous residence in Bulgaria, who do not present any of the above documents, will be quarantined for a period of 10 days at home or in another place of accommodation, in which the person has indicated that he/she will reside, with a recommendation issued by the Director of the respective Regional Health Inspectorate or a Deputy Director.  https://archive.vn/7Sbkz
No policy change.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220109210329/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ikonomicheski  http://web.archive.org/web/20220109211606/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/3103
No policy change.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220109210329/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ikonomichesk

Bulgaria has a Unified Information Portal for information on measures to combat the spread of covid-19 in Bulgaria including health, economic and social consequences of the epidemic.  https://archive.fo/Rtpk9

PCR testing is widely available at sites across the country, including hospitals and private laboratories. Currently 100 hospitals and laboratories in Bulgaria are officially accredited by the Ministry of Health. The fee is generally approximately $100 and is fully covered by the U.S. Citizen. It is preferable, to make an appointment by phone as most of the hospitals have specific time slots during which citizens can get tested.https://archive.vn/7Sbkz

Any person who has made contact within 48 hours before and up to 14 days after the onset of symptoms in a patient should be considered when determining close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19. If the confirmed case is asymptomatic, contact is any person who has been in contact with the case within 48 hours before up to 14 days after taking the sample that led to the laboratory confirmation.    Close contacts who have recovered as confirmed cases of COVID-19 are considered to be at low risk for SARS-CoV-2 transmission and are not subject to mandatory quarantine for a period of three months from laboratory confirmation of infection, except in cases where they work with at-risk populations (adults, people with chronic illnesses and immunosuppressive conditions) or live in places at high risk of infection as specialized social care institutions or prisons. In the case of contact with a confirmed case after the expiry of this period, the contact person should be considered as a close contact if he meets the above conditions.  https://archive.vn/Q1lSK

All persons must wear a mask that covers their mouth and nose in all indoor public spaces as well as in open public spaces where there is a crowd of people and it is not possible to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m. Scarves or substitute face coverings are no longer allowed in place of a mask.  https://archive.vn/7Sbkz
AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna are available. Availability is fluid and based on supply. General vaccination has started and can be booked.   https://archive.vn/7Sbkz
No extra measures of protection for elderly people are found to be in place for Bulgaria.   https://archive.fo/Rtpk9
No policy change.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220206213612/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/3100  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206213656/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/700
From 22 December, children over the aged 5 to 11 can be vaccinated against COVID-19 with the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine.  https://archive.fo/h8yaM
Vaccines are free for everyone. It doesn't matter if you have health insurance or not. If you want to be immunized, visit a GP or immunization center.  https://archive.fo/1aN37

No change in policy.    Employers should take the following measures:  Ensure that all surfaces in your workplace are clean and hygienically correct. Use alcohol-based disinfectants (minimum 70%).  Clean contact points in buildings at least three times a day, such as door handles, window handles, faucets in toilets and kitchens, cistern buttons, remote controls, power switches, door bells, elevator buttons, reception desks and more touch surfaces used by a large number of people.  Touching contaminated surfaces by employees and clients is one of the main ways the COVID-19 virus spreads.  Clean all touch surfaces at least twice a day: desktops, smartphones and other phones, laptops, keyboards, and computers according to user instructions.  Meeting rooms, trainings and other areas where a large number of people gather should be cleaned after each meeting.  Place hand sanitizers in visible places everywhere in the work environment, especially in public places where people have fewer opportunities to wash their hands regularly. Ensure that these funds are regularly updated.  For hand washing in toilets, provide warm running water and soap, as well as disposable paper towels.  Install waste bins with lids to safely dispose of used paper towels and other waste in toilets and other rooms.  Place the instructions on proper hand washing in a visible place in the toilet.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228131602/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/preporuke

No policy change.  Exceptionally, the new Order allows the organization of larger gatherings indoors and outdoors, provided that the size of the space allows the implementation of hygienic and epidemiological measures, but not more than 60 people indoors or 200 people outdoors, provided that all participants together have a negative antigen test (not older than 24 hours) or a PCR test (not older than 48 hours) or a certificate of overcoming COVID-19 (not older than 4 months) or a certificate of completed vaccination (not older than 6 months after receiving the second vaccine doses, ie 9 months after receiving the third vaccine dose).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228133317/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

Provision of services in catering facilities takes place with a distance of at least 2 meters between tables, and catering facilities that organize live music, disco clubs, as well as facilities for similar purposes must implement VPT (vaccinated, ill, tested, rule) with the obligatory observance of a distance of at least 2 meters between the tables.    In the part of the Order for sports competitions, it is allowed to hold outdoor sports competitions in the presence of spectators, in compliance with general hygienic and epidemiological measures, and indoors in the presence of spectators, subject to the application of VPT rules (vaccinated, ) and a distance between spectators of at least 2 meters.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228132129/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/867/na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-staba-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva

In the part of the Order for sports competitions, it is allowed to hold outdoor sports competitions in the presence of spectators, in compliance with general hygienic and epidemiological measures, and indoors in the presence of spectators, subject to the application of VPT rules (vaccinated, ) and a distance between spectators of at least 2 meters.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228132129/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/867/na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-staba-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva

No policy change.  It is allowed to gather people in a certain area under the following conditions:  no more than 30 people indoors;  no more than 100 people in the open.  All gatherings within the stated limits must take place in a space that allows a mandatory physical distance of at least 2 meters between persons (except members of the same household).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228133317/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

Hygienic and epidemiological measures must be observed at all indoor gatherings, and a physical distance of at least two meters must be maintained, and all participants in gatherings that bring together more than 300 people indoors must have:      â¢ negative antigen test, not older than 24 hours or PCR test, not older than 48 hours, or      â¢ a certificate of illness of COVID-19, not older than 4 months, or      â¢ confirmation of completed vaccination (not older than 4 months after the second dose of vaccine, or 12 months after the third dose of vaccine);    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228132129/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/867/na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-staba-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva

No policy change.  It is mandatory to wear a mask in the open if a distance of 2 meters cannot be achieved. It is mandatory to wear masks at public transport stops, markets / open markets and other places where there is a greater fluctuation of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228133317/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

The new Order , which is in force since February 24, 2022. year, it is still mandatory to wear a mask indoors (with a distance of at least 2 meters) in all health care institutions, institutions that care for the elderly, institutions that care for and accommodate people with disabilities and people with mental disorders, criminal correctional and other social protection institutions, as well as means of public transport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228132129/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/867/na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-staba-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva

No policy change.    A foreigner who meets conditions for entry to BiH prescribed by Law on Aliens, may enter BiH if he/she at the BiH Border Crossing Points presents any of the following:    negative PCR test or rapid antigen test on SARS-CoV-2, not older than 48 hours if he/she comes from an European country, and if he/she comes from another country, not older than 72 hours until arrival at the border crossing point ofBosnia and Herzegovina,    certificate that a person has received the second dose of vaccine for COVID-19 before more than 14 days before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH or has received one dose before 14 days and more before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH, if it is a single dose vaccine,    certificate issued by doctor showing that he/she has recovered from COVID-19 in the previous period from 14 to 180 days until the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205125253/http://www.granpol.gov.ba/Content/Read/76?title=Stranci&lang=en

No change in policy.    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228142523/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy.    The new order continues to instruct the competent authorities in the cantons / counties, as well as the health institutions in the cantons / counties, to provide COVID-19 vaccination points at the level of each municipality in order to make COVID-19 vaccination more accessible to the public. They are also required to organize vaccinations against COVID-19 every working day, at least three times a week until 20:00, at least one day during the weekend, and at least once a week at larger public gatherings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220115120320/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

ORDERS FOR INSTITUTIONS WHICH CARE FOR AND ACCOMMODATION OF ELDERLY PERSONS, INSTITUTIONS FOR CARE FOR ACCOMMODATION PERSONS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES AND PERSONS WITH MENTAL DISABILITIES    1. They are also required to organize vaccinations against COVID-19 every working day, at least three times a week until 20:00, at least one day during the weekend, and at least once a week at larger public gatherings.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220115120320/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih    Has the government of BiH approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Schools  Compulsory schools and upper secondary schools (e.g. baccalaureate and vocational schools), federal high school and vocational college final exams and continuing education: Masks must be worn in indoor areas of upper secondary schools. All other measures for compulsory schools and upper secondary schools are the responsibility of the cantons.    Tertiary level (e.g. universities, universities of applied sciences and colleges of higher education) and continuing education: Access to certain educational offerings and exams in this area is limited to people who are vaccinated or recovered or have a certificate for a negative test result (3G). Masks must be worn. You will find further details in the explanatory notes to Art. 19a of the Ordinance on Measures during the Special Situation to combat the COVID-19 Epidemic.    Recreational courses: The rules for events apply, i.e. basically the mask and certificate requirement (vaccinated or recovered, 2G) in indoor areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

No change in policy. Still required to wear a mask in schools.    There is still a requirement to have precautionary measures in place for publicly accessible areas, such as social distance, sanitisation, masks and partitions.    Precautionary measures are designed to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. For this reason, establishments, businesses, schools and , event organisers must implement specific precautionary measures.    Precautionary measures: requirements  Special provisions for restaurants, bars and canteens  Special provisions for events  Protecting workers: requirements  Precautionary measures: requirements  All publicly accessible establishments and businesses that are permitted to open, as well as events, require a precautionary measures plan.    In order to prevent the coronavirus from spreading again, it is still important to keep an appropriate distance, wash your hands thoroughly and regularly, and to wear a mask and erect partitions where necessary.      The same requirements apply to all these sectors of the economy. The requirements are regulated by the COVID-19 Special Situation Ordinance (Art. 10 and Annex). There are no longer any model precautionary measures plans. However, business sectors and associations may still refer to them as an aid. Businesses are still required to produce and put in place a precautionary measures plan. Information on precautionary measures can also be found on the SECO website (in German, French or Italian).    The following applies in all situations: People showing symptoms of illness should stay at home and get tested.    The precautionary measures must be drawn up to take into account the following requirements:    1.     They must provide for measures governing hygiene (e.g. possibility of washing or disinfecting hands, regular cleaning of surfaces) and ventilation.    2.     They must additionally ensure that the requirements for the mandatory wearing of masks can be met (particularly in publicly accessible indoor areas of establishments and businesses).    3.     Measures relating to maintaining distance, unless access for people over age 16 is restricted to those with a certificate. The precautionary measures must make it possible for people to observe the necessary distance while entering the establishment, business or event too. This does not apply for access to public vehicles.    4.     A person must be named who is responsible for the implementation of the precautionary measures and who is the contact person for the cantonal authorities.    Precautionary measures for publicly accessible facilities and businesses, including educational establishments, and the organisers of events with a COVID certificate requirement must also include measures to implement restrictions on access (e.g. performing access controls or informing visitors of the need for a certificate).    Specific information on the requirements for precautionary measures can be found in Annex 1 to the COVID-19 Special Situation Ordinance.    The establishments, businesses and organisers themselves are primarily responsible for implementing these precautionary measures. Neither the federal government nor the cantons approve precautionary measures plans; the precautionary measures are only checked as part of the approval process for large-scale events. The cantons are responsible for monitoring compliance and for conducting inspections.    The requirements with regard to precautionary measures may change depending on the situation. Be sure to check regularly that your precautionary measures meet the latest requirements.    https://archive.fo/EiouI  https://archive.fo/rjt1j

Work  Recommendation to work from home: Working from home is recommended in all areas where it is possible to work from home without disproportionate effort.    COVID certificate: Employers may check whether their employees are vaccinated or recovered or have a certificate for a negative test result (3G) if this is necessary for deciding on appropriate precautionary measures or for implementing testing concepts. The information on immunity status or the test result may not be used for any other purpose. Employees must be consulted on the use of the certificate and the measures derived from this, and these must be documented in writing. On data protection grounds, employers must use the âlight certificateâ with minimised data wherever possible.    Masks compulsory indoors: Masks are compulsory for all employees in indoor areas where several people are present. Exceptions apply in situations where a mask cannot be worn for safety reasons or owing to the nature of the activity as well as to people who cannot wear a mask for medical reasons. In particular, there is no exception to the mask-wearing requirement if it is an establishment in which employees meet the 2G+ requirements (vaccinated/recovered within last 4 months or vaccinated/recovered with negative test).    Protection in the workplace: Information can be found (in German, French and Italian) on the page Precautionary measures and on the page People at especially high risk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Masks required in healthcare settings    Protecting workers: requirements  Employers are not required to draw up and implement precautionary measures provided their businesses are not accessible to the public. However, they are required to ensure their employees are protected in accordance with the ordinance. This means employers must ensure that their employees can comply with the hygiene and distancing recommendations and the mask-wearing requirement indoors.    Employers must make sure that their employees can meet their work obligations from home wherever the type of work allows and it is possible for them to do so with proportionate effort. Employers must take appropriate organisational and technical measures.     Employers must also introduce further measures applying the STOP principle (Substitution, Technical measures, Organisational measures, Personal protective equipment). These include, for example, physical separation, separate teams or regular airing/ventilation. Employers now have the option of requesting that employees show a COVID certificate and of using this information to ensure adequate protection.    https://archive.fo/EiouI  https://archive.fo/rjt1j

Events  Indoors    Access to indoor events for people aged 16 and over is basically restricted to people who are vaccinated or recovered (2G).    Exempt from this COVID certificate requirement are:    Religious ceremonies, funerals, events that fall within the scope of the normal activities and services of public authorities, political events and self-help groups with up to 50 people. For these indoor events, masks must be worn, the consumption of food and drinks is banned.  Blood donation campaigns are not considered events and are therefore not subject to the COVID certificate requirement. The current precautionary measures continue to apply to these campaigns.  Basically masks must be worn for all events indoors. Where neither wearing masks nor compulsory seating is possible, only vaccinated or recovered people who can present a certificate for a negative test result (2G+) are admitted.    You will find more detailed information on the various areas of application of the COVID certificate and the exceptions on the Use of the COVID certificate page.    Outdoors    At outdoor events, access for people aged 16 and over is also restricted to people who are vaccinated or recovered (2G). The organiser can voluntarily limit access to vaccinated or recovered people who also have a certificate for a negative test result (2G+).Access restrictions can be waived if not more than 300 people are admitted and guests do not dance. Precise details may be found on the Precautionary measures page.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

17/2/22    From 17 February: Almost all measures lifted  From Thursday, 17 February, the following protective measures will be lifted throughout Switzerland:  - mask requirement in shops, restaurants, as well as in other public settings (facilities, venues and events)  - mask requirement in the workplace  - access restrictions regulated by COVID certificate (3G, 2G and 2G+-rule) to facilities and venues such as cinemas, theatres and restaurants, as well as events  - permit requirement for large-scale events  - restrictions on private gatherings    In agreement with the Federal Council, voluntary capacity restrictions in the retail sector and in cablecars and gondolas will be lifted.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.admin.ch/gov/en/start/documentation/media-releases/media-releases-federal-council.msg-id-87216.html

Rule indoors without certificate: A maximum of 30 people is allowed if everyone is vaccinated or recovered. Who is not permitted to enter Switzerland?  Foreign nationals without proof of a recognised vaccination (see question Â«How can I prove that I am vaccinated?Â») seeking to travel to Switzerland from a SEM high-risk country for a stay here of up to three months without a visa and who do not meet any of the requirements under Â«Who is permitted to enter Switzerland?Â» are not permitted to enter Switzerland. These persons include:    Persons who wish to obtain services in Switzerland;  Tourists, visitors and participants in events;  Persons who wish to come to Switzerland for medical treatment that has not yet begun or that is not regarded as urgently required;  Persons seeking employment or who have been invited for a job interview in Switzerland;  Persons who wish to submit an application for a residence permit.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220164905/https://www.sem.admin.ch/sem/en/home/sem/aktuell/faq-einreiseverweigerung.html#-1871257744

Loss of earnings payments to continue for certain groups of people  Once measures are lifted, there will no longer be a need for most economic support measures. Therefore, claims for loss of earnings as a result of business closures, event bans, reduced working hours and a shortfall in outside care will no longer be possible from 17 February.      An exception applies until 30 June for persons working in the events sector whose employment is significantly restricted due to measures to combat the COVID-19 epidemic. An exception also applies until the end of March for persons who have to interrupt work due to their need to protect themselves. Overall, the rapid lifting of measures should result in a reduction in expenditure of several hundred million Swiss francs  compared to the budgeted amounts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220218091949/https://www.admin.ch/gov/en/start/documentation/media-releases/media-releases-federal-council.msg-id-87216.html      All employees have protection under the short-time working scheme.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130074141/https://www.arbeit.swiss/secoalv/en/home/menue/unternehmen/versicherungsleistungen/kurzarbeit-covid-19.html

11/2/22  As of 20.12, the Swiss government pays for tests (both anti-gen and PCR tests) that are needed for a COVID-19 certificate.    Test costs for certificates will be covered again  The Federal Council has also decided that the costs of certain Covid-19 tests that lead to a Covid certificate will be covered again in future. In doing so, he is implementing a parliamentary decision in the Covid 19 law. Rapid antigen tests and saliva PCR pool tests are to be paid for. Self-tests, individual PCR tests and antibody tests are not paid for. The costs of individual PCR tests for people with symptoms of illness, for contact persons and after positive pool samples are also covered. The new test cost system will apply from tomorrow, Saturday, December 18, 2021. From January 17, 2022, everyone who takes part in repetitive tests must also be able to obtain a test certificate.    Only one test upon entry for vaccinated and recovered people  After consulting the cantons, the Federal Council has also adjusted the test regime upon entry, which will apply from Monday, December 20, 2021. Before entering Switzerland, in addition to PCR tests that are not are older than 72 hours, rapid antigen tests that are not older than 24 hours are also accepted. The obligation to have a second test 4 to 7 days after entering Switzerland is waived for vaccinated and recovered people.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211221065541/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-86544.html

11/2/22  Entry where a certificate is required has strict criteria around the process placed upon venue owners.    Entry checks with the COVID certificate  When letting people in, it is important that event organisers check the validity of the COVID certificate via COVID Certificate Check and always check against matching photo identification (e.g. ID card, passport, driving licence, residence permit, student card). In addition, organisers of large-scale events must obtain a cantonal permit. The COVID certificate is the only permissible document for entry. This applies to both the Swiss COVID certificate and to recognised foreign certificates (e.g. the EU Digital COVID Certificate). Youâll find more information for checkers and issuers on the COVID certificate on the corresponding page.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

The general rule of thumb applies: Always wear a mask indoors when you are away from home and you are unable to maintain social distancing of 1.5 metres from other people at all times.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

26/2/22  On 17th February most restrictions were lifted by the federal government    Masks  In enclosed areas of public vehicles as well as in publicly accessible indoor areas of hospitals and clinics, retirement and care homes, people age 12 and over must wear masks. Youâll find more detailed information on the Masks page.    Wearing of masks compulsory throughout Switzerland  The mask-wearing requirement applies throughout Switzerland on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. Besides the nationwide rules, the cantons can make wearing masks compulsory in additional areas and situations. For this reason you must always follow the cantonal rules.   Wearing of masks compulsory on public transport and on planes  You must wear a mask in enclosed areas of the following public transport services and facilities:  Trains, trams and buses  Mountain railways, cable cars and chair lifts  Ships and boats  Aircraft (all scheduled and chartered flights taking off or landing in Switzerland)  Note: Masks are compulsory at all times, no matter how many people are travelling. If you refuse to wear a mask on public transport, you may be asked by the transport staff to get off at the next stop. If you refuse to do so, you may receive a fine. You may remove your mask briefly to eat or drink on public transport.     Wearing of masks compulsory in publicly accessible areas  To protect particularly vulnerable people, in certain situations masks must be worn in publicly accessible indoor areas of hospital, clinics, retirement and care homes.   Wearing of masks compulsory at work  Your employer has a duty to protect you. For this reason you should find out from your employer what requirements apply in terms of mask-wearing. You will find more information on the SECO website (in German).  Exemptions from the requirement to wear a mask  Children under the age of 12 do not have to wear a mask (cantonal exemptions may apply). Masks are available in childrenâs sizes. Adult masks can also be folded and the straps shortened to fit childrenâs faces (recommended for surgical masks).  General exemptions from the requirement to wear a mask on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. In the following cases, you do not have to wear a mask (regardless of your age):  You can prove that you are unable to wear a mask for a specific reason. Such reasons include, for example, facial injuries, shortness of breath, conditions such as dementia and Alzheimerâs, anxiety when wearing a mask and disabilities that make wearing a mask intolerable or impossible. All medical grounds must be substantiated with a certificate from a doctor or psychotherapist. You will find detailed information in the factsheet from the FBED and FOPH on mask dispensing for certain people with disabilities in the Documents tab.  You are a patient in a hospital or clinic: You can take off your mask when you are in your room(s).  You are resident in a retirement or care home.  Masks in everyday life  In any situation in which you want to give yourself and others additional protection you can decide for yourself whether you want to wear a mask even if doing so is not compulsory. Itâs still recommended to wear a mask particularly in enclosed and poorly ventilated spaces.    https://archive.fo/yREMb

https://archive.ph/ML7FX#selection-143.15-147.20  A travel ban is in place for countries with widespread occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 virus variants of concern (referred to as areas of variant of concern). Transport companies, e.g. air carriers and railway companies, may not transport any persons from these countries to Germany. There are only a few, strictly defined exceptions to this travel ban, namely for:  German citizens and persons who are resident in Germany with a current right to reside in the country, as well as their spouses, partners (if entering Germany from outside the EU or the United Kingdom / Northern Ireland: only partners living in the same household) and minor children  persons catching a connecting flight who do not leave the transit zone of a passenger airport and  few other special cases.  Persons qualifying for these exceptions must nevertheless complete a digital entry registration before entering the country, undergo mandatory testing or provide proof of immunity, and comply with the applicable quarantine regulations for travellers entering the country.

The current short-time allowance regulation expires on 31 March. The Federal Cabinet has therefore initiated [updated] regulations will subsequently apply until 30 June 2022. The requirements for access to short-time allowance will remain reduced. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211155508/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis

Lauterbach announced a change in the testing regulation this week. Among other things, there will continue to be prioritisation for those working in nursing homes and in the medical field. Furthermore, he said, it was planned that all people would also be entitled to PCR retesting after a positive Corona rapid test. In this way, one would have "an efficient, but also safe system" of testing. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211155508/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis

People are fully vaccinated or previously infected and able to document this, for example with a corona passport,  can enter from all countries without test or self-isolation.    FOR THE UNVACCINATED OR THOSE WHO WERE PREVIOUSLY UNINFECTED:    - Entry from countries in EU/Schengen: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from COVID-19 risk countries: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from all other countries (high risk countries): A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry within 24 hours after entry. Furthermore, there is self-isolation for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. Certain travellers (e.g. children under 15) are exempt from test and isolation requirements.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053540/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

Furthermore, there is self-isolation for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. For those who are vaccinated or previously infected, there are no travel restrictions when entering Denmark.    For those are not vaccinated or previously infected:  - There are no travel restrictions if you enter from EU or Schengen countries .  - Those entering from a country outside EU and Schengen, must take a test at a test centre within 24 hours upon entry (self-tests are not valid for this purpose). From 1 February 2022 there are no longer any restrictions in the social and elderly area. Thus there are no longer a requirement for corona passport for visitors etc. and requirements for the use of face mask or shield for visitors, etc. and employees on social services, etc.     If possible it is urged to continue arrangements for the display of corona passport and for the use of face mask/shield in nursing homes and social services with vulnerable residents/users. It is also urged with a continued focus on the test effort in relation to employees in the elderly care and on social services as well as visitors to nursing homes and social services.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

In general education, masks are recommended but covid-certificates are not mandatory.  In informal education and catering establishments, students must either be vaccinated, recovered or present a negative test (tests are accepted only for those under 18).     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306190941/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/restrictions-in-education-youth-work-hobby-and-sports-activities

COVID-19 certificate or proof of recovery is required to attend events and activities taking place indoor. Unvaccinated person could still go to work if employer agree upon risk analysis. Mask wearing is recommended in the work environment.     In commercial and service establishments, the persons responsible for the operations, the service providers and traders on whose sales or service area the person is have to monitor that the obligation to wear a mask is adhered to. The service provider or trader has the right to not allow entry to their sales or service area to a person who refuses to wear a mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306191605/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306203523/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/work-during-the-emergency-situation

Public meetings and events are allowed but participants who are 18 years old and older have to prove that they do not pose an infection risk by presenting a COVID certificate stating vaccination or recovery.  For children of 12 of 18, negative tests are accepted for their COVID certificate.  Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306191605/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#mask

All persons 18 years of age and older must present a COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery in order to participate in activities taking place in checked public spaces. A COVID certificate has to be presented to participate in sports, training, youth work, hobby activities and informal education, refresher training; at sports competitions, and sports and exercise events; in saunas, spas, water parks and swimming pools; at public meetings and events, including at the theatre, at the cinema, at a concert (including a church concert), at a conference; at museums and exhibition facilities; at entertainment services; at catering establishments in order to eat and drink on the premises.    For everyone, masks are mandatory in public spaces indoors and distance working is recommended.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306191605/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#mask
Masks must be worn in public transport  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306205713/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/public-services-and-everyday-life/public-transport-within-estonia
No stay at home requirements   https://web.archive.org/web/20220306210600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life
No restriction on internal movement.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306210600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life

Depending of the country of origin, the list of requirement changes. Travelers might have to get tested, self-isolate and might need to present an imperial reason to be allowed to enter Estonia (work, studying, family reasons, or under a special permit). Those who are fully vaccinated are exempt from these measures.    There's no particular testing or quarantine requirement for vaccinated persons / persons who have previously been infected with the COVID-19 disease.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306215934/https://www.kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/who-subject-restrictions
No financial support, except for sick leave.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306220829/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
No relief found.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306220829/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
A government website keep the public informed  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306222412/https://www.kriis.ee/en

It is possible to test for the coronavirus both for free (with a referral) and by paying. Free testing is provided for people who are symptomatic. It is possible to get a referral to testing by calling the Family Doctor.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220306222652/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/testing-for-the-virus
Contact tracing is done with the HOIA mobile app.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220306223204/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/hoia-mobile-app

A protective mask is obligatory in public indoor spaces (including rooms where COVID certificate is checked, e.g. cinema, theatre, events, trainings etc). Wearing a mask is not obligatory in activities where it is not possible, for instance, in direct sports and when coming in contact with water, as well as when eating on the premises of restaurants.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306223335/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/personal-protection-equipment---masks-and-similar

All residents of Estonia from the age of 12 are recommended to get vaccinated for free against COVID-19.  A parent can book an appointment for their child aged 5-11 to get vaccinated by contacting the child's family doctor.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306223654/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-in-estonia

Recommendations are made to protect elderly people.   Where possible, home-based services provided for the elderly by the local government of residence should be preferred to placement in a nursing home.  Residents of nursing homes should not be transferred between different homes.  Before meeting a person at risk, make sure you are safe from infection and ensure safety when meeting them: wear a mask, keep your distance, and clean your hands and surfaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306224037/https://www.kriis.ee/en/sickness-health-vaccinations/coronavirus-and-preventing-its-spread/prevention-coronavirus

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

The National Telework recommendation was officially ended on the 28th of February. It is now advised to shift to a combination of in-office and remote work gradually while maintaining the standard hygiene practices. The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with. No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

On return from the Winter holidays (either 21 February, 28 February or 7 March, depending on the region of the country - https://web.archive.org/web/20220216093310/https://www.education.gouv.fr/calendrier-scolaire-100148) the health protocol applied to schools moves from Level 3 to Level 2.     Three main changes now apply:     - The end of the obligation to wear a mask outdoors for elementary school students and staff;  - The possibility of practicing physical and sports activities indoors again without wearing a mask (respecting a distance: contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask);  - The lightening of the rules limiting social mixing (by level or group of classes rather than by class), especially during break times.    In addition, legal guardians of students who have been in contact with a confirmed Covid-19 case in their class will no longer be obliged to send a signed "Declaration of Honour" that their child has completed the proscribed regime of self-testing in order for them to return to school after isolation, and that testing regime will be relaxed to one self-test rather than two from 28 February.     There are no reported policy changes for colleges and Universities.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220225010222/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220306230622/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy - discotheques and nightclubs remain closed, but will be allowed to re-open on 16 February. Standing concerts are also prohibitied until that date.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220209213558/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    A Vaccine Pass is required for all employees and customers/visitors to:     - places of entertainment and leisure (cinemas, museums, theatres, sports and entertainment venues, libraries, and others)  - bars and restaurants;  - long-distance/inter-regioanl transport by plane, train or bus  - fairs, professional seminars and exhibitions  - stores and shopping centres (depending on the decision of the prefect)    the Vaccine Pass applies to all people aged 16 and over, and proves that the bearer has either completed a full vaccination schedule, has recovered from Covid-19 in the past 6 months, or has contraindications for vaccination. From 15 February, the rules relating to the Vaccination Pass are changing for people over 18 years and 1 month of age. The booster dose should be carried out as early as 3 months after the end of its initial vaccination schedule and within a maximum of 4 months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210095345/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071002/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

From 16 February, restrictions that banned standing concerts, consumption while standing in bars or cafes, and that enforced the closure of discotheques and nightclubs were lifted and such venues were allowed to re-open, subject to the provisions of the Vaccine Pass - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071002/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Under the provisions of the Vaccine Pass, all customers and employees who interact with the public in places of leisure and culture, commercial catering establishments, trade fairs and exhibitions, on long-distance inter-regional transport, at ski lifts or in tourist accommodation must posses a vaccine pass. Vaccination is also mandatory for all employees and service providers in health and medico-social establishments - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071010/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal
No cahnge in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220225003224/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Use of the Vaccine Pass is required to access inter-regional or long-distance public transport within France - https://web.archive.org/web/20220210095345/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal    Local public transport is unaffected by this restriction, although face coverings are required - https://web.archive.org/web/20220210094109/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Use of the Vaccine Pass is required to access inter-regional or long-distance public transport within France - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071010/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal    Local public transport is unaffected by this restriction, although face coverings are required and will continue to be required after facial covering restrictions are lifted in other areas of daily life on 28 February - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071010/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal

A Vaccine Pass is required to use inter-regional or long-distance public transport within France.
