From 4 February, the classification of countries from which travelers are subject to differentiated border controls based on health indicators is as follows:     - "Green" countries and territories: countries or territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay*, Vanuatu.  *Uruguay will move from the Green List to the Orange List as of February 6, 2022.  - "Orange" countries: countries in which there is an active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions, without diffusion of worrying variants. These are not all countries included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries.  - "Red" countries: countries in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. To date, there are no countries classified as "red".  - "Scarlet red" countries: countries in which a particularly active circulation of the virus and the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape are observed. To date, there is no country classified as "scarlet red".    Anyone aged 12 and over entering French territory must present a negative PCR or antigen test of less than 24 hours or 48 hours depending on the country of origin. The only exception is that people with a complete vaccination schedule do not have to be tested when arriving from a Member State of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See or Switzerland.    Specific rules in place for travel to and from the UK were relaxed on 4 February from those implemented in January. As of this date, travelers from the UK are included in the provisions of travelers from the list of Orange countries, with the nuance that unvaccinated travelers from the UK must provide results of a PCR or antigen test taken within 24 hours of travel, and within 48 hours for vaccinated travelers.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205210857/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements     1/ travelers from a country/territory classified as "green"  1.1: for the Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland:  Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    This obligation does not apply to the travel of road transport professionals in the exercise of their activity and to the following trips by land:    Journeys of less than 24 hours within a perimeter defined by a radius of 30 kilometres around the place of residence;  Business travel whose urgency or frequency is incompatible with the performance of a test or screening examination.  1.2: for Bahrain, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, United Arab Emirates and Vanuatu:  All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status, from these countries/territories must present a negative PCR test or antigen test (GAD) taken less than 48 hours before the flight for boarding. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2/ travellers from a country/territory classified as "orange": all countries/territories other than those mentioned in paragraph 1 ("green")    - All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status, must present a negative PCR test or antigen test (GAD) taken less than 48 hours before the flight. For unvaccinated travellers from the UK, the time to complete the PCR or antigenic test is 24 hours.    All travelers will be eligible for an antigen test upon arrival. In addition:    - vaccinated travellers (full vaccination schedule) are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons.  - unvaccinated travellers are subject to the imperative grounds regime and will have to commit to a 7-day self-isolation and undergo a test at the end of this period. The list of compelling reasons is specified in the travel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235349/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 6 February, Uruguay moves from the Green to the Orange list. There are no other policy changes. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172530/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 12 February, the classification of countries from which travelers are subject to differentiated border controls based on health indicators is as follows:     - "Green" countries and territories: countries or territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan and Vanuatu.  - "Orange" countries: countries in which there is an active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions, without diffusion of worrying variants. These are not all countries included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries.  - "Red" countries: countries in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. Currently, there are no countries classified as "red".  - "Scarlet red" countries: countries in which a particularly active circulation of the virus and the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape are observed. Currently, there is no country classified as "scarlet red".    In orer to enter France, travelers must comply with rules specific to their country of departure:     1: travelers from a country/territory classified as "green"  - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a PCR test of less than 72 hours or antigenic test (TAG) of less than 48 hours.  - This obligation does not apply to the travel of road transport professionals in the exercise of their activity and to the following trips by land:  -- Journeys of less than 24 hours within a perimeter defined by a radius of 30 kilometres around the place of residence;  -- Business travel whose urgency or frequency is incompatible with the performance of a test or screening examination.    2: Travellers from a country/territory classified as "orange": all countries/territories other than those mentioned in paragraph 1 ("green")  Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a PCR test of less than 72 hours or antigenic test (TAG) of less than 48 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    In addition:     - vaccinated travellers (full vaccination schedule) are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons.  - unvaccinated travellers are subject to the imperative grounds regime and will have to commit to a 7-day self-isolation and undergo a test at the end of this period. The list of compelling reasons is specified in the travel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    Whilst no countries are currently specified as Red or Scarlet Red, nnvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories would still be subject to the regime of compelling reasons for entering France, must present at boarding a negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight, will be subject to a mandatory antigen test upon arrival, and would be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine,controlled by the security forces.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220213064422/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19     The specific rule requiring travelers from the United Kingdom to present results of a Covid-19 test taken within 24 hours of departure (rather than the usual 48 hours requires for travelers from other Orange list countries) has been rescinded as of 12 February. https://web.archive.org/web/20220213064422/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19 and https://web.archive.org/web/20220221213430/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/france/entry-requirements

From 16 February, the categorisation of Green / Orange list countries has been updated as follows:     "Green" countries/territories : countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Bahrain, Cape Verde, Cambodia, Colombia, South Korea, CÃ´te d'Ivoire, Cuba, The United Arab Emirates, Ecuador, Gabon, Ghana, Guinea, Equatorial Guinea, Guinea, Honduras, Hong Kong, Fiji, Mauritius, Samoa, Islands, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, Laos, Mauritania, Morocco, Nepal, Chad, New Zealand, Nicaragua, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Vanuatu, Venezuela and Vietnam.    "Orange" countries/territories : countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" countries/territories.    There are currently no countries categorised as Red or Scarlet Red.     Entry regulations applicable to travelers from these countries are unchanged. https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071051/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Policies relating to the allowances paid to employers whose employees are obliged to reduce the number of hours worked were updated for the period 28 January to 28 February 22, providing:     - 36% of the employee's previous gross salary within the limit of 4.5 SMIC with a floor of â¬7.53    - 70% of the employee's previous gross remuneration (i.e. approximately 84% of the net salary), within the limit of a remuneration of 4.5 SMIC, with a floor of â¬8.37 per hour, regardless of the company's workforce  -- in establishments open to the public and closed by administrative decision to combat the spread of the covid19 epidemic  --in establishments located in a reconfined territory when they suffer a 60% loss of turnover either in relation to the turnover recorded during the month preceding the implementation of the reconfinement, or in relation to the turnover recorded for the same month in 2019.  -- for employers belonging to so-called protected sectors (S1, S1 Bis) and which suffer a decrease in turnover of at least 65 % compared to the turnover recorded for the same month in 2020 or 2019, in respect of the turnover achieved over the previous six months compared to the same period in 2019, compared to the average monthly turnover achieved in 2019 or, for companies created after 30 June 2020, in relation to the average monthly turnover achieved between the date of creation of the company and 30 june 2021 (before 1er December 2021, this drop in turnover had to be at least 80%) or subject to health restrictions. These companies can benefit from the partial activity scheme without any remaining expenses. The derogation of partial activity without remaining at the expense of these employers is renewed.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172553/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/dispositif-de-chomage-partiel    There are no changes to the policies supporting the self-employed - https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172612/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/reponses-gouvernement-difficultes-independants

Some relaxation in facial covering requirements, as from 21 February as schools return from Winter holidays (21 or 28 February, or 7 March depending on region) masks no longer need to be worn outdoors by elementary school students and staff. Face coverings are also no longer required for indoor school physical and sports activities where social distancing is possible (so, contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask). https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Face coverings are still required on public transport and in some enclosed public spaces such as stadiums, concert halls, and theaters - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071002/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Some relaxation in facial covering requirements, as from 21 February as schools return from Winter holidays (21 or 28 February, or 7 March depending on region) masks no longer need to be worn outdoors by elementary school students and staff. Face coverings are also no longer required for indoor school physical and sports activities where social distancing is possible (so, contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask). https://web.archive.org/web/20220225010222/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Face coverings are still required on public transport and in some enclosed public spaces such as stadiums, concert halls, and theaters, but will be further relaxed from 28 February when face masks will no longer be required in places accessible by Vaccine Pass holders - https://web.archive.org/web/20220225003224/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over, with one parent's permission required for children aged between 5 and 11.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all those who work in contact with frail people. Thus, since September 15, 2021, the following must be vaccinated:    - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting APA or PCH, in home services or as employees of individual employers;  - staff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.  - Persons justifying a contraindication to vaccination are exempt from the vaccination obligation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172651/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all staff of medical and medico-social institutions (including administrative staff), supporting services, and those who work in contact with frail people.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Maximum gatherings  A maximum of 100 people can gather in one place. It is no longer a free public service to get tested for COVID-19. From the 1st March 2022 it is no longer possible til book a COVID-19 PCR-test from the hospital system.  Looking forward, people who need a PCR-test from the hospital system will be informed by a relevant healthcare professional.  People who need a PCR-test for other reasons, for example in connection with travel on a vacation or for work abroad, need to contact a private laboratory.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220302043144/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

As of February 15, 2022:  Quarantine guidelines will be further eased such that only those who receive positive results from PCR or quick tests will be required to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220209040107/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

It is no longer a recommendation that people infected with COVID-19 shall quarantine.  Each one of us is individually responsible for whether we are exposing others to infection. Keeping a distance and hygiene is the best protection against infection.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220302043144/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en
No policy recommendation for facial coverings.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220209040107/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

Rules for non-vaccinated changed on 11 February, meaning that non-vaccinated people do not need to quarantine upon arrival in the UK. Rules as follows:    Fully vaccinated â from 11 February  If you qualify as fully vaccinated for travel to England, you:    will not need to take a COVID-19 test before you travel to England or after you arrive  will not need to quarantine when you arrive  You will need to complete a passenger locator form before you travel to England.    Check if you can follow the rules for people who are fully vaccinated â includes people aged 17 and under.    Not fully vaccinated â from 11 February  If you do not qualify as fully vaccinated for travel to England, you will need to:    show proof of a negative COVID-19 test â test to be taken in the 2 days before you travel to England  book and pay for a COVID-19 PCR test â to be taken after you arrive in England  complete a passenger locator form before you travel to England  You will need to book the PCR test before you travel.    You will not need to quarantine, unless the result of the PCR test is positive.      http://web.archive.org/web/20220210131053/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19    http://web.archive.org/web/20220211134511/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19

24 February    Fully vaccinated: Before you travel to England you must complete a passenger locator form. You need to do this in the 48 hours before you arrive in England.    Not fully vaccinated: Must complete PCR test but from 24 February, there is no legal requirement to self-isolate if you get a positive day 2 test result.      http://web.archive.org/web/20220224030744/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19    http://web.archive.org/web/20220225155734/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19

A negative PCR test is required to enter Georgia unless a passenger is fully vaccinated and arriving by air. Unvaccinated passengers will additionally have to submit a travel history in advance of entering Georgia and take another PCR test on day 3 of arrival in Georgia.The requirement to self-isolate is terminated for unvaccinated visitors who are citizens or residents of listed countries provided the above conditions are met.   Travelers arriving by land or sea must be citizens or residents of listed countries and travel must be directly from a listed country.  If you present proof of having been infected with COVID within the previous 100 days and have had the first jab in a two-dose vaccination process, you do not need to test or quarantine to enter Georgia if you arrive by air.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220228223253/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/georgia/entry-requirements    http://web.archive.org/web/20220228213312/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/

Greece will reopen schools as scheduled on Monday amid record coronavirus cases, the government has decided. Greece reintroduced measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic amid concern that rising cases will pile pressure on the nationâs health care system.    As much as 50% of all private and public-sector employees will have to work from home between Jan. 3 and Jan. 16, Health Minister Athanasios Plevris said Monday. The government also ordered restaurants, bars, cafes and night clubs to close at midnight.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

All those travelling to Greece (aged 5 or above) must show proof of a professionally administered negative rapid COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before arrival or proof of a professionally administered negative PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival.     The measure affects all arrivals, regardless of vaccination status or country of departure. The only exception is for arrivals who have spent less than 48 hours in a country prior to arriving in Greece.                                              Random antigen testing on arrival applies to every arrival to Greece, regardless of the certificate in their possession. If you are selected, please keep in mind that the screening is mandatory and in case of refusal, authorities reserve the right to refuse entry into the country.    If you are selected for a test and test positive, you will be subject to mandatory quarantine, for which you may be required by the Greek authorities to move to a designated quarantine facility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161137/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/greece/

Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. Learn more in the section If you are an other contact.  -However, roommates at boarding schools etc., must follow the guidelines for close contacts.  Last updated Wednesday 9. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129063601/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/guidelines-for-primary-schools-day-care-and-after-school-activities/

Corona passport (digital EU COVID certificate)  -People in Greenland who have been vaccinated can get a corona passport.  -You can use a corona passport e.g. if you are travelling abroad and you need to document that you have been vaccinated against COVID-19. In some countries, you must show your corona passport or documentation of previous infection upon arrival.  https://archive.vn/lWkU1    Area restrictions  -There is no longer an inventory of cities and settlements with spread of infection from unknown sources. Conditions for entry into Greenland  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.    You are considered fully vaccinated immediately after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccine to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -If you are not a resident in Greenland, you must bring documentation that you are fully vaccinated or a positive PCR test result which, at the time of departure, is at least 14 days and at most 12 weeks old  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must bring a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must show a lease, employment contract or something else that documents your move  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years and older.  *updated policy  https://archive.vn/uwO8J

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -Special rules apply if you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks. Read more in the section âPreviously infected with COVID-19â here.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccine to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -If you are not a resident in Greenland, you must bring documentation that you are fully vaccinated.  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must bring a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must show a lease, employment contract or something else that documents your move  https://web.archive.org/web/20220201102406/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.    Requirements to enter Greenland by air or sea:  People who are 12 years old or older must be able to document one of the following things in order to enter Greenland by air or sea:  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must document this with a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency. You can download your certificate of residence at sullissivik.gl.  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must be able to document that you have a job or a home in Greenland. For example, you can use a rental contract, a contract of employment or a letter from your coming employer as proof.  -If you are not a resident of Greenland you must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and able to provide documentation proving this.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated. Only vaccines approved by EMA are accepted.  -Furthermore, you must live up to the rules on use of face masks during travel to Greenland.  Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://archive.ph/dDMhY

If you test positive:  Test result  -If your test result is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your result from a PCR-test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the health department / corona secretariat.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215024602/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

Domestic travel in Greenland:  -Face masks  It is not required to wear a face mask on domestic flights in Greenland.  Last updated Friday 11. february    Use of face masks and visors  -Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you MUST wear a face mask in the following situations:  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  -If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129080932/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

Good advice for people at a higher risk:  -In general, if you are someone who is at a higher risk, you can continue to do the things you did before the COVID-19 pandemic, e.g. go to work, participate in leisure activities and take care of your grandchildren.  -If before the COVID-19 pandemic, you had to follow special precautions in your daily life to avoid being infected with an infectious disease, e.g. you have a special condition and are immunocompromised, you should continue to follow those precautions.    The National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) recommends the following for persons who are at a higher risk:  -Get re-vaccinated  -Follow the recommendations from the Office of the Medical Director of Health and ask others to be mindful  -Avoid large events and gatherings of people where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider using a face mask in public spaces where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider talking with your workplace about how to ensure that you can go to work safely    The older you are â the more and more serious chronic diseases have â the more attention you need to pay to following the recommendations. You must naturally take your quality of life into consideration, when you place limits on your life.  *Risk groups and highly vulnerable people  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215030314/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/

Regardless of the vaccination status, submitting regular rapid tests are now required (since 09/ FEB) every week.    /web/20220214231445/https://www.koronavirus.hr/upute-ravnateljima-o-primjeni-modela-ukidanja-samoizolacija-u-osnovnim-i-srednjim-skolama-uz-provodenje-redovitog-dobrovoljnog-samotestiranja-ucenika/1004

No change in policy.  Self-testing on SARS-CoV-2 rapid antigen tests is voluntary and free and is performed once a week. Although it is recommended that students self-test on Mondays before school (or Sundays before bedtime), testing can be done on another day of the school-specific week, depending on when the first test is delivered to each school. It is important that the self-test is performed once a week and that the interval between the two tests is equal. For example, parents / guardians may record a negative test result in a student's notebook presented by the student at school or may report it in another way determined by the school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219124852/https://www.koronavirus.hr/upute-ravnateljima-o-primjeni-modela-ukidanja-samoizolacija-u-osnovnim-i-srednjim-skolama-uz-provodenje-redovitog-dobrovoljnog-samotestiranja-ucenika/1004

In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interfering with workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. No policy change    Restrictions for Individuals and Businesses  Businesses and individuals may be restricted due to the epidemiological measures based on your location in Croatia.    As of January 10, 2022, the Government of Croatia is imposing a range of epidemiological measures:    Indoor public gatherings are limited to 25 people.  Outdoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 50 people.  Outdoor public gatherings where everyone has EU digital certificates are limited to 200.  Private ceremonies will be limited to 20. Exception: private ceremonies in which everyone has a covid certificate will be limited to 50 people.  Sporting events and competitions: Indoor sports facilities may operate with up to 20 percent of spectator seating occupied. Outdoor events may operate with up to 40 percent of spectator seating occupied.  Catering / Dining establishments will be under more robust and compliance checks.  Individual counties and cities may have additional measures. Please visit?the?Croatian Governmentâs COVID-19 website?for additional information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214092352/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quarantine Information:  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? No  Travelers may be ordered to self-isolate or spend up to 14 days in official government quarantine facilities if deemed necessary to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Placement in quarantine is at the expense of the traveler.  Travelers who do not receive self-isolation orders are given a?Pamphlet with Recommendations and Instructions?from the Croatian Institute of Public Health that they must follow for 14 days after entering the country.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220214092352/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy.  The necessary epidemiological measure of self-isolation is automatically determined for all passengers in transit, including personnel in the transport sector, if they do not leave the Republic of Croatia within 12 hours from the moment of entering the Republic of Croatia.    Citizens of EU Member States (including Croatian citizens), i.e. Schengen Member States and Schengen associated countries, as well as members of their families and third-country nationals who are long-term residents under Council Directive 2003/109/EC of 25 November 2003 concerning the status of third-country nationals who are long-term residents and persons entitled to reside under other EU directives or national law or who have national long-term visas and are coming from third countries, must present a valid EU Digital COVID Certificate when entering the Republic of Croatia.    Exceptionally, the abovementioned category of passengers who do not yet possess an EU Digital COVID Certificate will be allowed entry into the Republic of Croatia if they have the following:     negative PCR test result or rapid antigen test result - RAT for SARS-CoV-2, where the RAT test must be listed in the Common list of rapid antigen tests recognized by the Member States of the European Union, published by the European Commission. If the RAT test results were made abroad, the manufacturer and/or the commercial name of the test must be visible. Otherwise, it will not be accepted as credible for entering the Republic of Croatia.  The PCR test result must not be older than 72 hours and the RAT test result must not be older than 24 hours, counting from the time the test was taken until the arrival at the border crossing point;   certificate that they have received two doses of vaccine used in the EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax) or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since receiving the second dose of the vaccine, or a certificate that they have received one dose of the vaccine if the vaccine is administered in a single dose (Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose, or a certificate that they have received the booster dose of the vaccine;  certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax, Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) or a vaccine approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac), provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 270 days from their arrival at the border crossing point;  positive PCR test result or rapid antigen test result, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 180 days and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or  a medical certificate of recovery;  or if they perform PCR testing or rapid antigen testing - RAT for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon their arrival in the Republic of Croatia (at their own expense), with the obligation to stay in self-isolation until they obtain a negative test result. In case they cannot get tested, they have to self-isolate for seven (7) days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219130513/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

COVID-19 Testing  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Croatia? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  A test can be arranged at the following locations:?COVID-19 Testing Locations in Croatia.  The cost of a local test (rapid antigen test or a PCR test) ranges from $40 to $150 or more, depending upon the location, and the result can be expected between 1-48 hours depending upon the type of the test.  Effective December 6, 2021, all airline passengers to the United States ages two years and older must provide a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within one calendar day of travel. Alternatively, travelers to the U.S. may provide documentation from a licensed health care provider of having recovered from COVID-19 in the 90 days preceding travel.? Check the CDC website for additional information and?Frequently Asked Questions.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page:? https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/before-you-go/covid-19_testing_required_US_Entry.html  Travelers departing Croatia from Zagreb can test at the Dr. Franjo Tudman Airport in Zagreb.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214092352/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219125454/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No changes.   Schools are opened. Only mask-wearing. In crÃ¨ches, kindergartens, schools, principals and in higher education institutions, rectors, and in other workplaces, employers can determine the rules for wearing a mask.   Source: https://archive.vn/OTDms
Schools are fully open.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228190945/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

No changes.  Workplace are working via Covid-19 restrictions - mask-wearing, distancing.  BUT for some groups of people, workplaces could be closed:  -Vaccination is expected in the public sector, and mayors can decide on it.  -Confirmatory third vaccination is also required for health care and some public administration workers.   -Employers may require the vaccine to be taken. For unvaccinated workers, the employer may set a 45-day deadline for taking the first vaccination.   Source: https://archive.vn/OTDms  -From 3 January, teachers who have not been vaccinated by 30 December will be on unpaid leave, the Ministry of Human Resources (EMMI), which is responsible for education, said.   Source: https://archive.vn/cXNtQ

Employers are allowed to require their employees to be vaccinated, either as a standard working condition for all workers or as an individual working condition, depending on the job. For workers who have not yet been vaccinated, the employer may set a deadline of 45 days for taking the first vaccination. Vaccination is expected in the public sector, and mayors can decide on it.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Events of more than 500 people can only be attended with a security card. Also, mask-wearing.  So, vaccines required to enter large concerts and sporting events. No exception.  Source: https://archive.vn/OTDms    The 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' (EUDCC) is required to access some public spaces, such as bars and restaurants, museums, large events, and some means of public transport.   Source: https://archive.vn/XxhwO

All indoor events and outdoor events with more than 500 people attending require an immunity certificate. This certificate is provided to all those who have received their first vaccine dose). It is valid for six months after the second vaccination, after which it will only be extended is the third booster dose has been given. After the third booster dose, the certificate will be valid indefinitely.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191612/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/coronavirus
Events of more than 500 people can only be attended with a security card.  Source: https://archive.vn/XxhwO

Events of more than 500 people can only be attended by those with an immunity certificate. This certificate is provided to all those who have received their first vaccine dose). It is valid for six months after the second vaccination, after which it will only be extended is the third booster dose has been given. After the third booster dose, the certificate will be valid indefinitely.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191612/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/coronavirus & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Masks are required on all public transport, and proof of immunity is also required on some means of public transport.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228193937/https://wiki.unece.org/display/CTRBSBC/Hungary & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
No stay at home recommendation or restriction requirements for both vaccinated or non-vaccinated.  Source: https://archive.vn/OTDms

There is no curfew. People who suspect they have the virus are asked to stay at home and avoid going out into the community.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

No restrictions on internal movement. Whilst proof of immunity is required on some means of public transport, there is no physical restriction on unvaccinated people moving within Hungary.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228193937/https://wiki.unece.org/display/CTRBSBC/Hungary & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Non-essential travel to Hungary is only allowed to Hungarian citizens who hold an immunity card; non-Hungarian nationals who provide proof of vaccination; non-vaccinated - recovery from COVID-19 or a negative test result.    For vaccinated: required to be vaccinated to enter.  For non-vaccinated: Hungarian citizens without vaccination certificates, returning from abroad, are obliged to stay in home quarantine for 10 days from the date of entry. Passengers returning home may be exempted from quarantine if they provide a certificate containing the negative results of two SARS-CoV-2 molecular tests performed in Hungary at two different times, with at least 48 hours between them.     Source: https://archive.vn/XxhwO

People entering Hungary must agree to enter mandatory quarantine unless one of the following applies:  - You are in possession a Hungary issued Immunity Certificate, EU Covid certificate, or obtain UK proof of vaccination (final dose must have been administered at least 14 days prior to travel)  - You have a negative PCR test from the past 72 hours  - You are arriving by road, rail and waterway from one of Hungaryâs neighbouring countries,  - You meet one of the exemptions for vaccination  It is possible to leave quarantine early following two negative COVID-19 tests within 5 days of each other but at least 48 hours apart.  Unless you are a Hungarian national, or arriving on land from a neighbouring country, people entering Hungary will be subject to a temperature check on arrival.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228194631/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/entry-requirements

No changes.  The government is providing several significant subsidies:  -Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, public employees can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.  Sources: https://archive.vn/OTDms

Several measures are in place:  - parents receive a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the average wage tax level.  - Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium of HUF 80,000 in November and will receive a full refund  of their 13-month pension in February 2022 .  - Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  - Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax from January 2022.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

No changes.  The government is providing several significant subsidies:  -Parents receive a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the tax level of the average wage.  -Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium  of HUF 80,000 in November and will receive a full refund  of their 13-month pension  in February 2022.  -Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  -Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax from January 2022.  The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, public employees can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year. No changes.  There are dedicated governmental supportive websites with daily information on cases and policies, additionally extra campaign regarding vaccination and additional information about COVID-19.   Sources: https://archive.vn/OTDms; https://archive.vn/oKO9P
Up to date information is available via a publicly available website.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

A PCR test for coronavirus is ordered in all people who are suspected of having a coronavirus. This is ordered by your GP, epidemiologist or hospital and is completely free.   Source: https://archive.vn/OTDms

Anyone suspected of having COVID-19 can order a test through their GP or a hospital for free. Outside of this, the officially regulated price for a PCR test is 19,500 HUF, with antigen tests being offered from 8,500 to 15,000 HUF. Some facilities offer express results for an additional fee.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191128/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

There is mobile contact tracing app - VirusRadar. VirusRadar mobile application uses Nextsense Contact Tracing Technology for the detection of potentially exposed persons to Covid-19, implemented in StopKorona! mobile app.   Source: https://archive.vn/tlC8T

A contract tracing app (VirusRadar) was launched in May 2020, but there is no evidence of its broad or consistent use.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228195241/https://nextsense.com/ns-newsarticle-virusradar-a-mobile-contact-tracing-implemented.nspx

Remaining restrictions  The following restrictions remain in place until 28 February 2022:    - Requirement of a vaccination or recovery certificate for international travel  - Use of face coverings to continue where currently required (for example, in shops and on public transport)  - Requirement to self-isolate if you have symptoms of COVID-19 and close contact guidance to remain in place  - Protective measures in primary and secondary schools and early year settings to remain in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211203513/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

The Government has approved plans to remove almost all Covid-19 related restrictions next Monday (28th Feb)    In schools and childcare pods for children, staggered breaks and physical distancing can also end from Monday. These settings will still be required to practice good hygiene and have good ventilation, while children should stay at home if they are sick.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226075802/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/cabinet-agrees-to-drop-almost-all-remaining-covid-19-rules-from-monday-1.4808912

Remaining restrictions  The following restrictions remain in place until 28 February 2022:    - Requirement of a vaccination or recovery certificate for international travel  - Use of face coverings to continue where currently required (for example, in shops and on public transport)  - Requirement to self-isolate if you have symptoms of COVID-19 and close contact guidance to remain in place  - Protective measures in primary and secondary schools and early year settings to remain in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211203513/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

Remaining restrictions  The following restrictions remain in place until 28 February 2022:    - Requirement of a vaccination or recovery certificate for international travel  - Use of face coverings to continue where currently required (for example, in shops and on public transport)  - Requirement to self-isolate if you have symptoms of COVID-19 and close contact guidance to remain in place  - Protective measures in primary and secondary schools and early year settings to remain in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211203513/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

Since 1 February 2022, a standard acceptance period of 14 days after the final dose in a primary vaccine series of a vaccine will be required for all vaccines accepted for travel to Ireland.    You are fully vaccinated when it is:    14 days after the second AstraZeneca dose or second Covishield dose  14 days after the second Pfizer-BioNtech dose  14 days after the second Moderna dose  14 days after the single Janssen dose  14 days after the second Sinopharm dose (also called Vero Cell Inactivated)  14 days after your second dose of Coronavac (Sinovac)  14 days after your second dose of Covaxin  14 days after your second dose of of Novavax (Nuvaxovid)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222092310/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/travel_and_recreation/travel_to_ireland/travel_to_ireland_during_covid.htmla

From 6 March 2022, all COVID-19 travel restrictions are removed. You no longer need to complete a passenger locator form. You also no longer need proof of vaccination or recovery, or a COVID-19 test.    You should follow public health advice if you develop symptoms of COVID-19 or if you are a close contact of a confirmed case of COVID-19.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220308070549/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/travel_and_recreation/travel_to_ireland/travel_to_ireland_during_covid.html

Remaining restrictions  The following restrictions remain in place until 28 February 2022:    - Requirement of a vaccination or recovery certificate for international travel  - Use of face coverings to continue where currently required (for example, in shops and on public transport)  - Requirement to self-isolate if you have symptoms of COVID-19 and close contact guidance to remain in place  - Protective measures in primary and secondary schools and early year settings to remain in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211203513/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

By law, you must wear a face covering when using public transport. This includes in taxis, as well as in bus and rail stations.    Mask wearing will still be required in the following settings:    public transport, taxis and at stations/airports/ports  retail premises (including shopping centres, libraries, cinemas, theatres, museums, post offices, banks, credit unions), public offices and at premises providing specified services and businesses (incl. salons, hairdressers, travel agents, laundries, dry cleaners, bookmakers)  workers in customer facing and food preparation roles in premises where food and beverages are sold for consumption on the premises  healthcare settings    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222092940/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/0fc0d-government-announces-that-most-of-the-public-health-measures-currently-in-place-can-be-removed/?referrer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gov.ie%2Fen%2Fpublication%2F3361b-public-health-updates%2F      From 28 February 2022, it is no longer mandatory to wear a face covering on public transport, in taxis, shops, schools and other indoor public areas. Staff in hospitality settings will no longer need to wear a face covering. . You are still recommended to wear a face mask in hospitals and health settings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222091958/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/face_coverings_during_covid19.html

The Government has approved plans to remove almost all Covid-19 related restrictions next Monday (28th Feb)    Under a plan that went to Cabinet, all legal requirements to wear masks will expire after February 28th, with their use only required in healthcare settings. Since 1 February 2022, a standard acceptance period of 14 days after the final dose in a primary vaccine series of a vaccine will be required for all vaccines accepted for travel to Ireland. 28/02/22    The Rakning C-19 app  Infection tracing is a social issue  The C-19 app is an important tool in the comprehensive work carried out here in Iceland with regard to COVID-19 and can be of great assistance to hinder the spread of the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228212624/https://www.covid.is/app/en

28/02/22    Face masks  Face masks must be worn wherever the 1 meter social distancing rule cannot be observed between people who are unrelated.    Mask obligation does not apply to children born 2006 or later.    Face masks must be used where it is not possible to ensure 1 meter of social distancing, such as in healthcare services, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities. Face mask needs to cover both nose and mouth.    Those who do not have the understanding or maturity to use a face mask correctly or are unable to do so for other reasons, such as health reasons, do not have to wear a mask.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221212536/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

28/02/22    Effective restrictions on gatherings  As of Friday 25 February 2022 all public restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic will be lifted, both domestically and at the border.  Limits to the number of people at gatherings are none  Social distancing rules are none  Masks are not mandatory anywhere  Restrictions on any kind of operations are no longer applicable, neither the obligation to register guests nor restrictions on opening hours  Personal infection preventative measures are encouraged and if we experience symptoms we get tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228210608/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

For most countries, except for European countries, it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered), if this is not done people will only be admitted if they have residency or working permits, and will therefore have to self-quarantine. For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211173255/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

From March 1st almost all restrictions have been removed. The only restrictions still in place are to show a "green pass equivalent" certificate (so not a vaccine mandate).  Vaccinated people therefore just need to show their vaccination status, unvaccinated people need to show a negative test or proof or recent recovery from Covid. In case a proof of vaccination or recent recovery cannot be provided they will need to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303173230/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301212105/https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/da-oggi-piu-facile-viaggiare-stop-quarantena-e-green-pass-base-chi-entra-italia-paesi-extra-ue-AEx0F3GB

Until Feb 10th mask mandates are in force throughout Italy, irrespective of vaccination status.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204132115/https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/covid-ecco-calendario-l-allentamento-restrizioni-italia-AEPfLvBB    From Feb 11th Facial Masks are not mandatory in the open spaces (in White, Yellow and Orange zones) when social distancing can be guaranteed:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211210735/https://tg24.sky.it/cronaca/2022/02/11/covid-come-cambiano-regole#03

From Feb 11th masks are not required outside when social distancing can be guaranteed.  The Campania region though still enforces masks everywhere.  Mask mandates are irrespective of vaccination status throughout Italy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220216144835/https://www.quotidiano.net/napoli/covid-campania-oggi-15-febbraio-1.7367334  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211063744/https://www.corriere.it/cronache/22_febbraio_08/mascherine-aperto-11-febbraio-c619385e-8859-11ec-8804-7df4f9fb61d8.shtml

Quote: "Travelers must provide a negative PCR test.  PCR tests must be taken no more than 72 hours before arrival into Kyrgyzstan. As of February 11, 2021, travelers may show their original vaccine card showing proof of  As of February 11, 2021, travelers may show their original vaccine card showing proof of vaccination against COVID-19 instead of a negative PCR test.  Travelers without vaccination or valid PCR results will be denied entry.  Children under age 5 are exempt from testing or vaccination entry requirements." Quote: "24-hour COVID testing is available at Manas International Airport. Other local labs may have extended operating hours but do not provide 24-hour service. Travelers should plan accordingly to ensure that they will have current test results prior to boarding their flight(s).  The Ministry of Health provides free testing only for symptomatic patients. For those requiring a negative PCR test for travel, state laboratories in Bishkek and Osh can provide tests for a fee (approximately $20), depending on testing capacity. Private COVID-19 testing is also available for a fee ($30) at Bonetsky Laboratory or Aqualab. "  Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220217132813/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools are fully open. Masks and spit tests are available on a voluntary basis.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133458/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140102/https://www.regierung.li/files/attachments/20220216-Medienmitteilung-60-COVID-19-Regierung-hebt-Massnahamen-auf.pdf?t=637820888994325498

The work from home message has been lifted, though employers can still put protection measures such as masks or work from home recommendations in place as they see fit.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140102/https://www.regierung.li/files/attachments/20220216-Medienmitteilung-60-COVID-19-Regierung-hebt-Massnahamen-auf.pdf?t=637820888994325498

As of the 16th of February 2022, private and public events can be held and attended without Corona protection measures in place or COVID certificates required. There are no restrictions on private gatherings, though public gatherings with audience still have a cap of 1000 people.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140637/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/coronavirus

Public transport is operating. All over the age of 12 are required to wear a mask in trains, trams, and buses, as well as on mountain rail and cableways and on lake and river boats.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140405/https://ch.usembassy.gov/covid-19-info/

There are no recommendations or requirements to stay at home; people who test positive must still isolate for a period of at least 5 days.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus
There are no restrictions in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140405/https://ch.usembassy.gov/covid-19-info/

The same rules for entering Switzerland apply to entering Liechtenstein. You may only enter if you are fully vaccinated, with the final vaccine dose having been delivered in the past 270 days; if you are fully vaccinated, no negative test or entry form is required. If you are not fully vaccinated, and are not an EU, Swiss, or Liechtenstein national, or holder of a residency permit, you may not enter the country.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134613/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134849/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/entry-requirements

It is possible to apply for and receive short-time work compensation due to the economic consequences of the pandemic. This is officially in place until the end of March 2022, with the possibility of extension until June 2022.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305143517/https://www.serviceportal.li/de/medienmitteilungen/moeglichkeit-fuer-corona-bedingte-kurzarbeitsentschaedigung-soll-bis-juni-2022-verlaengert-werden & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305144018/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-84116.html
No measures found.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

The test centre in Vaduz in the Marktplatzgarage is open daily from 14:00 to 17:00. No appointment is necessary, and results are available within 24-36 hours. The test if free if you have health insurance, and you do not have to be symptomatic to order one.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

Per the Ministry of Economy and Innovation for Lithuania, When an enterprise declares inactivity due to an emergency or quarantine the worker shall receive at least the minimum monthly salary and shall not be required to arrive to work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228181226/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-3/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-2/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus

Per the Ministry of Economy and Innovation for Lithuania, Emergency tax loans, with deferred taxes, including suspension of taxes and paying fines and interest on loans are deferred. Face masks are required indoors (in trade and service provision points, institutions, companies, or organisations, at work and in education, during events, etc.). It is required that all spectators and participants over the age of 6 and the staff serving an event wear at least FFP2 respirators tightly fitting to the face and covering the mouth and nose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220214203/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

There are no restrictions on gatherings or events that take place in your private home. The CovidCheck disappears in private homes. The thresholds for gatherings are hereby amended as follows.  For gatherings  of up to 10 people, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed  Gatherings of between 11 and 50 people (inclusive): if the gathering is not organised under the CovidCheck system, the double condition of wearing a mask and a minimum distance of 2 metres is compulsory  Gatherings of between 51 and 200 people (inclusive): if the gathering is not organised under the CovidCheck system, the triple condition of wearing a mask, being seated and keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres is compulsory  Gatherings of between 201 and 2,000 people are in principle subject to the CovidCheck system, if not to the triple condition of wearing a mask, being designated a seat and keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres  Over 2,000 people, gatherings are authorised provided they are subject to a health protocol to be accepted in advance by the Health Directorate  The provisions regarding sports and cultural activities have been adapted to reflect the reintroduction of the 3G system. This system applies as soon as the number of people in the group exceeds 10.  https://archive.ph/Dskgx

Moldova requires anyone entering the country present one of the following:  1) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 2) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; or 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214230300/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Those with one of the following documents can enter Moldova without having to self-isolate.  - proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination, with second dose administered at least 14 days before arrival  - negative result of a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before time of arrival  - negative result of a rapid antigen test taken no more than 48 hours hours before time of arrival  - a confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test  All those without this documentation must complete an online epidemiological form and self-isolate for 14 days. Self-isolation can stop after 7 days with a negative PCR or antigen test.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220219193312/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/moldova/coronavirus

Those with one of the following documents can enter Moldova without having to self-isolate.  - proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination, with second dose administered at least 14 days before arrival  - negative result of a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before time of arrival  - negative result of a rapid antigen test taken no more than 48 hours hours before time of arrival  - a confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test  All those without this documentation must complete an online epidemiological form and self-isolate for 14 days. Self-isolation can stop after 7 days with a negative PCR or antigen test.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220224060715/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/moldova/coronavirus

No changes in policy.  Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021. A comprehensive fiscal package has been adopted as per two 2020 State Budget Amendments, following several targeted fiscal measures to support businesses and vulnerable households, such as expanding unemployment benefits and strengthening existing targeted social assistance, tax relief for sectors affected by state-imposed restrictions, delaying tax payment deadlines to mid-2020, suspending tax audits and other controls, and increasing state budget allocations to the budget emergency and health funds and to a mortgage guarantee program. The approved 2021 Budget envisages more support to the health sector, and farmers support.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214190729/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change. COVID-19 testing is available at both public and private medical laboratories. People who do not have Moldovan health insurance and a Moldovan family doctor can go to a private medical laboratory to request a test. Prices range from 700 to 800 Moldovan lei (MDL) (approximately $40-50).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214230300/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

"From Friday 18 February all locations in the Netherlands will be allowed to stay open until 01.00. Until 25 February, the coronavirus entry pass (3G) must be shown at locations where this is currently mandatory, such as restaurants, bars, cinemas, theatres and music venues and at professional sporting events. Once you are inside any of these locations, the rules on assigned seating, wearing a face mask and keeping 1.5 metres apart will no longer apply and capacity will no longer be limited. At locations accommodating more than 500 people, however, assigned seating and face masks will still be mandatory. "  https://archive.fo/M1c8X#selection-155.0-155.611

"On Friday 25 February we will take the final step. From then, opening times will return to normal and we will lift the following requirements: showing a coronavirus entry pass (3G) at locations accommodating fewer than 500 people, staying 1.5 metres apart, wearing face masks while walking around bars and restaurants, schools and shops, having a limited number of visitors, and assigned seating in bars, restaurants and other venues. That means that large night clubs, discotheques, festivals and events can open up without limitations. At indoor locations accommodating more than 500 people where there is no assigned seating, for example night clubs and festivals, everyone must show a negative test result. This does not apply at events where there is a continuous flow of visitors, such as trade fairs and conferences. To ensure that vulnerable people are able to travel safely, the requirement to wear a face mask on public transport and at airports will remain in force even after 25 February."  https://archive.fo/M1c8X#selection-163.0-166.0

"Events and gatherings  The regulatory requirement of operation in accordance with the infection control rules in the COVID-19 Regulations is repealed. This means that most of the requirements regarding event/gathering sizes or making arrangements so people can keep a distance have been removed for organisers.  However, there is still a requirement to have infection control measures in accordance with the Regulations relating to measures in the environment to promote health, which state that enterprise's operations must be planned and carried out in a manner that prevents communicable diseases.  Normal operations in accordance with the general infection control rules for the population are recommended."  https://archive.fo/Te4ca#selection-2147.0-2167.108

11/2/22  Education  From Thursday, January 27 to February 27, 2022, students of grades 5-8 of primary schools and all grades of secondary schools take classes in a remote form.    Students in grades 1- 4 of primary schools continue their education in a full-time mode.    Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Nurseries and kindergartens  Nurseries and kindergartens are open and provide care for children.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112116/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja

Education  From Thursday, January 27 to February 18, 2022, students of grades 5-8 of primary schools and all grades of secondary schools take classes in a remote form. Students in grades 1-4 of primary schools continue their education in a full-time mode.    From February 21, 2022, all students will return to full-time education.     Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Nurseries and kindergartens  Nurseries and kindergartens are open and provide care for children.    Illness, quarantine or isolation of the child  A person covered by sickness insurance is entitled to an allowance in the event of necessity to care for a sick child, including when the child has been subject to isolation or quarantine. Care allowance may also be used by a parent who has to look after a healthy child up to the age of 8 due to the unexpected closure of the institution the child attends.    You can learn more about the care allowance on the ZUS website .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211112845/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja

25/2/22  All students have returend to school.    From February 21, 2022, all students returned to full-time education.     Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Face masks are still required    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225131746/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.
