4/3/22  From 1st March Rules have been relaxed and masks are now required indoors only.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304082256/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

11/2/22    Attention! The number of persons vaccinated against COVID-19 is not counted if they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Museums and art galleries  They function in a strict sanitary regime. There is a limit of people - 1 person. on 15 m2.    Cinemas  They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    It is not allowed to eat or drink in the cinemas.    Theaters, operas, philharmonics  Outdoor:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners.    In rooms:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners. Ensuring that no more than 1 person per 15 m2 of the area is present in the room at the same time. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    Houses and centers of culture  Conducting activities by cultural centers and centers as well as community centers is allowed in the open air and indoors, provided that the participation does not exceed 30%. participants. Ensure that participants follow the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus performances  Events may take place under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,    keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience and ensure that no more than 1 person per 15 square meters is present in the room at the same time,    ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus performances may be organized outdoors under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,    keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience,    ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Outdoor amusement parks  Amusement parks may operate at up to 30%. occupancy.    Libraries  Possibility to make collections available, provided that no more than 1 person per 15 mÂ² is present in the library, with the exception of librarians. Before entering the library, information about the limit of people should be posted.    Conducting activities by public and scientific libraries consisting in the organization of meetings and events is allowed indoors, provided that:    while maintaining a distance of 1.5 m between participants;    that participants comply with the obligation to cover their mouth and nose.    Night clubs, discos and other places available for dancing  Nightclubs, discos and other places to dance have closed. 4/3/22  Current rules  Attention! Check the current safety rules. How quickly we deal with COVID-19 depends on our shared responsibility. From March 1, we lifted the limits and restrictions with the exception of: isolation of the patient and quarantine for a co-household member, incoming quarantine, the obligation to wear masks in closed rooms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304083038/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

Assembly  All types of meetings may be attended by up to 100 people. Participants are required to keep 1.5 m away from other people. In addition, the distance between assemblies must not be less than 100 m.    Meetings  Up to 100 people can participate in outdoor events and meetings, either in the premises or in a dedicated social area . There is a distance between the tables (every second table can be occupied, the distance between the tables must be at least 1.5 m - unless there is a partition at least 1 m high between them, counting from the surface of the table) .    Weddings, communions, consolations and other celebrations  You can organize special events outside and inside (e.g. in a restaurant). There is a limit of people - max. 100. Such events could take place in strict sanitary regime. There is a distance between the tables (every second table can be occupied, the distance between the tables must be at least 1.5 m - unless there is a partition at least 1 m high between them, counting from the surface of the table) .    go to end view    https://web.archive.org/web/20220204133826/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zgromadzenia-i-imprezy

4/3/22  Current rules  Attention! Check the current safety rules. How quickly we deal with COVID-19 depends on our shared responsibility. From March 1, we lifted the limits and restrictions with the exception of: isolation of the patient and quarantine for a co-household member, incoming quarantine, the obligation to wear masks in closed rooms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304083038/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

11/2/22    Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128094644/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

From March 1, we lifted the limits and restrictions with the exception of: isolation of the patient and quarantine for a co-household member, incoming quarantine, the obligation to wear masks in closed rooms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304083038/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

11/2/22    Attention!  If your trip started from the territory of the Republic of Botswana, the Kingdom of Eswatini, Lesotho, the Republic of Mozambique, the Republic of Namibia, South Africa or the Republic of Zimbabwe , you cannot shorten the quarantine - you will be there for 14 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121113541/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/granice-i-ruch-miedzynarodowy

Rules for travelers coming to Poland from European Union Member States, from the Schengen area and others  If you are traveling with:    European Union Member States,  Switzerland  Iceland,  Norway  Liechtenstein,  Principality of Andorra,  Principalities of Monaco,  The Republic of San Marino,  Vatican City State  you are subject to a 7-day quarantine.     You are not quarantined if:    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU digital COVID certificate or other document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate,  You will present a negative COVID-19 test result:  certified by the EU digital COVID certificate or other document in Polish or English,  the test must be performed no earlier than 48 hours before crossing the border,  You are 12 or under and traveling with adults who are vaccinated against COVID-19 or tested negative for COVID-19.  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.  If you have been quarantined, you can perform a test up to 48 hours after crossing the border, the negative result of which will release you from quarantine.    Also check who is exempt from the obligation to quarantine after crossing the state border.    What test can I do?    Test type: RT-PCR and antigen test.  Tests are not publicly funded.  Are you a foreigner?    Check the border crossing rules for foreigners.    Traveler Location Card  A person who crosses the state border of the Republic of Poland by plane fills in the Traveler Location Card in an electronic form before check-in , and if this is not possible - a paper-based travel location card provided by the cabin crew.    The data administrator is the state poviat sanitary inspector competent for the place of residence or stay of the traveler.    EU COVID Certificate  The EU COVID Certificate is issued by the Ministry of Health. A vaccination certificate is issued:    in electronic form,  in paper form;  by providers of immunization against COVID-19,  by a primary care physician or primary care nurse.  Detailed information on the EU COVID Certificate .    Important! This communication is provided for information purposes only and cannot be used as a basis for adjudicating on a case-by-case basis. The verification on the basis of the document presented for inspection and the final decision on quarantine or grounds for exemption from such a requirement will be taken by a Border Guard officer who performs border control.    In disputed / doubtful / random matters regarding sanitary restrictions / quarantine / vaccinations - including the rules for exemptions, shortening its duration - the only competent authority is the State (Border) Sanitary Inspector at the local level, or a higher level authority, i.e. the Minister responsible for Health (Chief Sanitary Inspector).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221121222/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-ze-strefy-schengen

25/2/22  For those arriving from outside the Schengen area that are unvaccinated quarantine is required. For all vaccinated travellers a PCR test is required for entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214181845/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

25/2/22  For those arriving from outside the Schengen area that are unvaccinated quarantine is required. For all vaccinated travellers a PCR test is required for entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214181845/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

4/3/22  Rules for travelers coming to Poland from outside the European Union and from outside the Schengen area  Mandatory COVID-19 tests  People traveling from outside the European Union, from outside the Schengen area, must show a negative COVID-19 test result. You must complete the test regardless of the way in which you travel (collective, individual or on foot). Failure to test will require quarantine.    The obligation to perform the test also applies to vaccinated people or convalescents!    The test result must not be more than 24 hours prior to arrival.  The test can be performed at some airports in Poland - before border clearance or 3 hours after arrival (counting from border clearance).  quarantine   Attention! Persons crossing the Polish-Ukrainian border due to an armed conflict in Ukraine are not currently subject to the obligation to quarantine entry.    You are not quarantined if your antigen or PCR test is negative  and you meet one of the following conditions :    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU COVID Certificate or another document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate .  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.  Who is exempt from showing COVID-19 test results when arriving from outside the Schengen area?       Important! If you do not submit a negative test result, you must go into quarantine for  7 days .      What test can I do?    before crossing the border: RT-PCR or antigenic.  Tests are not publicly funded.    Important!     Persons who, after arriving from outside the Schengen area, the EU, stay in the territory of the Republic of Poland for no longer than 24 hours and have a flight ticket confirming departure from the territory of the Republic of Poland within 24 hours, may be exempt from the obligation to undergo quarantine, provided that:    show a negative result of the SARS-CoV-2 test (antigenic, PCR) performed within 24 hours before arrival to the Republic of Poland,  perform such a test before the border check (applies only to airports where it is possible),  perform the test at the airport after the border check within 3 hours.  Traveler Location Card  Each person who crosses the state border of the Republic of Poland by plane fills in the Traveler Location Card in an electronic form before check-in . If this is not possible, fill it in on a paper form provided by the cabin crew.    The data administrator is the state poviat sanitary inspector (sanepid) competent for the place of residence or stay of the traveler.    EU COVID Certificate  The EU COVID Certificate is issued by the Ministry of Health. A vaccination certificate is issued:    in electronic form,  in paper form;  by providers of immunization against COVID-19,  by a primary care physician or primary care nurse.  Detailed information on the  EU COVID Certificate .    Also check the  Border Guard website for information on quarantine after crossing the border.    Important! This communication is provided for information purposes only and cannot be used as a basis for adjudicating on a case-by-case basis. The verification on the basis of the document presented for inspection and the final decision on quarantine or grounds for exemption from such a requirement will be taken by a Border Guard officer who performs border control.    In disputed / doubtful / random matters regarding sanitary restrictions / quarantine / vaccinations - including the rules for exemptions, shortening its duration - the only competent authority is the State (Border) Sanitary Inspector at the local level, or a higher level authority, i.e. the Minister responsible for Health (Chief Sanitary Inspector).    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

11/2/22    Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206124352/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/jak-zrobic-test-na-koronawirusa-w-aptece

11/2/22    Limited contact tracing in place.    I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

11/2/22    Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  The nose and mouth may only be covered with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112908/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206100800/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

25/2/22  No change in policy    Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians. 11/2/22    We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

Quarantine for a specific group of countries seems to no longer be necessary, with Portugal adopting a list of countries for essential and nonessential traveling. It currently screens for the presence of one of the following certificates:   Mandatory  - A valid vaccination EU Digital COVID Certificate (with a complete vaccination schedule or with a complete vaccination schedule and a vaccine booster)  - Or a valid test or recovery EU Digital COVID Certificate,  - Or a valid vaccination certificate (with a complete vaccination schedule or a vaccine booster) or recovery certificate issued by a third country, https://web.archive.org/web/20220221151528/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the  evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the  institution.    4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as  in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical  presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of  the space.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

All employees of public institutions, central and local public enterprises, private  businesses, organizations, as well as other entities, must possess one of the following  evidence, in order to be allowed to enter the work premises:  4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Unless otherwise specified in this Decision, indoor gatherings of up to thirty (30) persons  (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other gatherings) are allowed. Except those  under the age of 12, participants are obliged to possess any of the evidence mentioned in  points 25.1 to 25.3 in order to be allowed to enter these premises, and the organizer is  obliged to provide a physical distance of one (1) meter between persons and check the  relevant evidence, such as:  25.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen  vaccine against COVID-19;  25.2 Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the  respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt  from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19,  which should not be older than 48 hours;  25.3 Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Restriction of citizens' movement shall be from 00:00 to 05:00, except:  13.1 Cases of an emergency nature (to seek medical help, purchase medication,  provide care or medical assistance, avoid injury, or escape the risk of injury);  13.2 Circulation for health, safety personnel, and operators performing public  works and services;  13.3 Night shift personnel of economic operators who ensure the functioning of  the supply chain (including transport of goods/services), but provided that  they are provided with a special permit from the EDI system of the Tax  Administration of Kosovo;  13.4 Persons who provide proof that they must be at the airport during the  circulation restriction, because they have to travel by plane;  13.5 Persons to whom a special temporary permit is issued by the Emergency  Operational Centre of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, according to point 15,  due to the necessity of circulation during curfew.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Every person who enters the Republic of Kosovo shall possess one of the following  evidence:  2.1 Certificate of full vaccination with two doses or a single-dose of Janssen  (J&J) vaccine not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last  dose;  2.2 Certificate of vaccination with a single dose accompanied with a negative  RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  2.3 Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90  days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  2.4 Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  2.5 Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours.    Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo who do not have two doses of vaccine are  obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the  entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo;     https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina and major towns in Kosovo.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  Are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turn-around time for results from the private clinics vary from several hours to 24 hours and are available via email and hard copy. Results from UCCK are reportedly available within 24 hours, but it is best to check with them due to expected higher demand.  If you are in Kosovo and have COVID-19 related questions, are symptomatic, or need information regarding testing, please call toll free 038 200 80 800, or dial 194.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse or recommend any particular healthcare provider, but below is a list of clinics and hospitals who are providing tests. Please contact them directly for details on location, tests offered, and pricing:  Medical and Laboratory Services SHPK, +383 48 111 000 or +383 38 600 188  Prolab, +383 49 789 410  Olive Lab, +383 38 720 055, +383 49 520 056  UBT â Laboratory I Microbiology e Clinic, + 383 46 500 777, +383 46 500 888  Avicena, +383 49 825 555  UCCK â University Clinical Center Kosovo (public hospital), +381 38 500 600    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211185746/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Are vaccines available in Kosovo for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes. The vaccine is available to both resident U.S. citizens and visitors without an appointment. For more details please see Kosovo Ministry of Health information available in Albanian and Serbian only.  Which vaccines are available in Kosovo? Astra Zeneca and Pfizer. The vaccine is limited to individuals over the age of 12.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211185746/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

From October 25, 2021 to April 1, 2022, metropolitan enterprises must transfer to remote work:  at least 30 percent of the total number of employees;  all workers over 60 years of age and suffering from chronic diseases. An exception is only for employees whose presence in the workplace is critical to the functioning of the organization.    In addition, in organizations where possible, it is recommended to transfer the maximum number of people to a remote mode of work.    Russia's Labor Ministry has recommended that all enterprises send as many of their employees to remote work as possible due to the surge in Covid-19 cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220218140404/https://tass.ru/obschestvo/13583061

An exception is only for employees whose presence in the workplace is critical to the functioning of the organization.    In addition, in organizations where possible, it is recommended to transfer the maximum number of people to a remote mode of work.    Russia's Labor Ministry has recommended that all enterprises send as many of their employees to remote work as possible due to the surge in Covid-19 cases. In Moscow, since November 8, 2021, it is mandatory to use a  QR code and a mask at concerts, entertainment, cultural, entertainment, sports and other events with the simultaneous presence of more than 500 people. Event organizers with less than 500 attendees are encouraged to make similar decisions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

The government of the Russian Federation requires the use of masks in crowded public areas, including public transportation, taxis, parking lots, and elevators. This order applies to the entire country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221231511/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

People above 60 in Moscow must stay at home or in their country house. They can go out only in these cases: when they need to go to the store, walk their pets, take out the trash, go to work, to the clinic or hospital, take a walk or play sports in the fresh air. They may also leave the house if there is a direct threat to life and health. These measures do not apply to those who have had COVID-19, as well as those who have been vaccinated against coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

They may also leave the house if there is a direct threat to life and health. These measures do not apply to those who have had COVID-19, as well as those who have been vaccinated against coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

Following widespread reports of military activity in Ukraine, on 24 February the Russian authorities announced restrictions on domestic flights to a number of airports in southern Russia, with disruption to internal flights to and from Moscow and other cities. The restrictions are set to be in place until 2 March 2022.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307230219/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/coronavirus

Starting from 10 December 2021, entry into Russia is not allowed for any passengers arriving from, or having visited during the last fourteen days, Botswana, Eswatini, Hong Kong, Lesotho, Madagascar, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Tanzania and Zimbabwe. However, there are numerous exceptions from this ban, which, for example, includes all Russian citizens.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206151156/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/entry-requirements

On 18 March 2020 the Russian government introduced restrictions on entry into the whole country for almost all foreign citizens. On 30 March 2020, temporary restrictions on entry and exit via Russiaâs land borders were enforced. The duration of these remains unspecified.    These restrictions were eased on 16 April 2021 for nationals and permanent residents of certain countries including the UK. They may now travel to Russia by air via authorised 3rd countries. The full list is subject to change and currently includes Albania; Andorra; Argentina; Armenia; Austria; Azerbaijan; Bahamas; Bahrain; Bangladesh; Belgium; Brazil; Bulgaria; China; Columbia; Costa Rica; Croatia; Cuba; Cyprus; Czech Republic; Denmark; Djibouti; Dominican Republic; Egypt; Ethiopia; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Hungary; Iceland; India; Iran; Iraq; Italy; Japan; Jordan; Kazakhstan; Kenya; Kuwait; Kyrgyzstan; Lebanon; Lichtenstein; Luxemburg; Maldives; Malta; Mauritius; Mexico; Moldova; Mongolia; Morocco; Netherlands; New Zealand; North Macedonia; Norway; Oman; Peru; Portugal; Qatar; Republic of Ireland; Republic of Korea; Republic of Seychelles; Saudi Arabia; Serbia; Singapore; Slovakia; Slovenia; Spain, Sri-Lanka; Sweden; Switzerland; Syria; Tajikistan; Thailand; Tunisia; Turkey; United Arab Emirates; United Kingdom.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307230828/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/entry-requirements

No changes in policy. Key measures include: (i) increased compensation for frontline medical staff as well as health and safety inspectors; (ii) individuals under quarantine received sick leave benefits and leave pay to equal at least the minimum wage until the end of 2020; (iii) for those who lost a job after March 1, 2020, including for sole proprietors, the standard unemployment benefit was equal the minimum wage for five months; the minimum unemployment benefit was tripled until end-August; and eligibility was extended by 3 months; the maximum unemployment benefit, which was increased in March 2020 to the minimum wage, will remain at the same level in 2021. (iv) all children up to 3 years of age received an additional lumpsum benefit for 3 months, starting in April 2020; all children 3-15 years of age eligible for a one-time lumpsum benefit; all children under 16 years of age eligible for another one-time lumpsum benefit; all families with children got an additional lumpsum benefit for each child for up to 6 months if a parent lost job (for up to 4 months for parents who lost their jobs before March 1); an additional lump-sum benefit for all kids under 8 years of age was announced at the end of December 2020; an additional one-off benefit to all schoolchildren as well as benefits for children in one-parent families was announced in April 2021; (v) interest rate subsidies for SMEs and systemically important enterprises; (vi) tax deferrals for most affected companies on most taxes; (vii) deferrals on social contributions for SMEs in affected sectors for 6 months (extended for three more months for selected affected sectors); (viii) social contributions by SMEs on wages in excess of the minimum wage permanently reduced; (ix) a tax holiday on all taxes (excluding VAT) and social contributions for Q2 2020 for SMEs, sole proprietors, and NGOs providing social services; (x) registered self-employed were refunded their taxes for 2019 and got a partial refund on their 2020 taxes; eligibility age to register as self-employed lowered from 18 to 16; (xi) sole proprietors got a partial refund on their social contributions; (xii) deferrals on rent payments to all levels of government until the end of 2020 plus zero rent to the federal government for three months for SMEs in affected sectors; (xiii) budget grants for SMEs in affected industries to cover salaries at the rate of one minimum salary per employee for two months plus subsidized and forgivable (under condition of preserved employment) loans for all enterprises in affected industries to pay minimum wages for 6 months; in 2021, enterprises in selected affected industries, like restaurants, hotels and entertainment, will get subsidized (but not forgivable) loans to pay minimum wages for 12 months, again under condition of preserved employment; (xiv) zero import duties for pharmaceuticals and medical supplies and equipment; budget grants will be extended in 2021 to firms hiring people who lost jobs in 2020 to cover their salaries at the rate of one minimum salary per employee for three months; (xv) guaranteed loans to SMEs and affected industries; (xvi) subsidies to airlines, airports, automakers, and others; (xvii) state-owned bank, airlines and development institution re-capitalization and (xviii) expanded eligibility for subsidized mortgage lending.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221223029/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No policy changes  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Testing is widely available in Russia, both through government healthcare providers and private clinics. Testing is free at government healthcare providers for those suspected of having coronavirus. In Moscow, residents of Russia who have mandatory medical insurance may schedule a free test at any time at one of 207 government healthcare providers in Moscow that provide testing. Private clinics also provide COVID testing on a fee-basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221231511/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The government of the Russian Federation requires the use of masks in crowded public areas, including public transportation, taxis, parking lots, and elevators. This order applies to the entire country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221231511/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Any citizen of the Russian Federation over the age of 18 can register for the vaccination. The Russian government has approved three domestically developed and produced vaccines for use in the country including Sputnik V, EpiVacCorona, and CoviVac. Additionally, service companies are required to vaccinate at least 80 percent of the total number of employees by January 1, 2022. Vaccination with the first component must be carried out before December 1, 2021. These measures were introduced by the decision of the chief sanitary doctor for the city of Moscow.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221231511/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

People above 60 in Moscow must stay at home or in their country house. They can go out only in these cases: when they need to go to the store, walk their pets, take out the trash, go to work, to the clinic or hospital, take a walk or play sports in the fresh air. They may also leave the house if there is a direct threat to life and health. These measures do not apply to those who have had COVID-19, as well as those who have been vaccinated against coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

The Authorities of the Republic of San Marino issued Decree-Law no. 3 of 14 January 2022 - Strengthening of provisions to avoid the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The provisions of the aforementioned Decree-Law, ratified by Decree-Law no. 6 of 21 January 2022, unless otherwise provided for, shall apply until the end of the health emergency, which is currently extended until 30 April 2022.         Entry into the Republic of San Marino, for those coming from countries other than Italy and the Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is permitted on presentation of the following documents:         A certificate of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2* or a certificate of recovery from SARS-CoV-2 within the previous six months. This certificate may be in paper or digital form;  Or    A negative coronavirus test certificate following a molecular or antigenic swab taken no later than 48 hours before entry and in any case in accordance with the health protocols in force in the Republic of San Marino. Any molecular swab taken within 48 hours prior to entry into the territory of the Italian Republic is considered valid for those who do not fall within the cases referred to in letter a) above.        Children under ten years of age are exempt from submitting the certificates referred to in letters a) and b).    https://web.archive.org/web/2021*/https://www.esteri.sm/pub2/EsteriSM/en/Covid/Covid.html

All retail stores may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week. No changes. Cafes, bars, and restaurants may now operate outdoor facilities with no closing time.  Indoor facilities may operate until 1:00 a.m.  Music is now allowed. All retail stores may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week. All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses. Up to 500 people are allowed to meet indoors or outdoors. Sports events may have spectators of up to 50% capacity in outdoor stadiums or 30% capacity in indoor arenas. Graduation celebrations are allowed. Events expecting over 500 people must get permission from the Crisis Response Team. Recreational classes and excursions may take place with consent from the Ministry of Education an competent institutions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307214010/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Starting December 20, 2020 the Government of Serbia is reporting that foreigners seeking to enter Serbia will need to provide a negative PCR test, not older than 48 hours. These measures are reported to not apply to several categories of travelers, including:  Foreign citizens in transit, with 12 hours allowed between entry to and exit from Serbia.  Minors up to 12 years of age, provided the parent, custodian or any other person accompanying the minor has a negative PCR test, if it is needed.  Crew and cabin crew of aircraft whose final destination is Serbia.  Crew, personnel, and passengers in transit through Serbiaâs international airports.  Accredited staff of foreign diplomatic and consular missions, as well as offices of international organizations. Also included are family members with diplomatic status in Serbia. Foreign citizens who have been granted temporary residence or permanent residence in Serbia.  As of July 24, 2021 the Government of Serbia is reporting that foreign citizens may enter Serbia without a negative COVID-19 test if they possess proof of recovery from COVID-19 at least 14 days prior to their entry and no more than 6 months prior to their entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307214010/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No change.    A supplementary budget with new support measures was adopted in April 2021. New measures include: (i) wage subsidies, including payment of Â½ of minimum wages for all entrepreneurs and employees in SMEs and large companies for three months (RSD 69.8 billion); (ii) additional payments for employees in travel, hospitality, and art (RSD 4.4 billion); (iii) universal cash transfer of EUR 60 to each citizen over 18 years old, paid in two installments of EUR 30 eachâin May and November (RSD 43.2 billion);(iv) a one-off payment of EUR 50 to all pensioners (RSD 10 billion);(v)a one-off financial assistance of EUR 60 to all the unemployed, paid in June (RSD 4.3 billion); and (vi) support for the transport sector and for city hotels (RSD 3.9bn); and a one-off payment of EUR 25 to all vaccinated citizens (RSD 9 billion). The total estimated cost amounts to 2.5 percent of GDP. It also includes additional healthcare spending and increased public investment (2 percent of GDP), mostly in infrastructure, environmental protection, and defense. The existing scheme for state guaranteed bank loans to SMEs has been expanded by EUR 500 million (1 percent of GDP) and a new EUR 500 million scheme for vulnerable companies has been established.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

In February 2021, the NBS and the ECB agreed to extend the duration of the precautionary repo line with the ECB to address possible euro liquidity needs of Serbian financial institutions. The repo line, initially planned to last until end-June 2021, has been extended for nine months, until end-March 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

During their stay in public places indoors, citizens are obliged to wear protective masks and maintain a distance of at least two meters between two persons who do not reside in the same household, in order to prevent the spread of the infectious disease COVID-19.    In public places in the open, if it is not possible to maintain a distance of at least two meters between two people (in front of shops, pharmacies, bus and other stops, etc.), wearing protective masks is mandatory. It is obligatory to wear protective masks in public road and rail transport of passengers. Parents of minor children or children with special needs, ie their guardians, are obliged to ensure that children older than four years wear a protective mask in the cases referred to in para. 1â3. of this article.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307222130/https://www.propisi.net/uredbu-o-merama-za-sprecavanje-i-suzbijanje-zarazne-bolesti-covid-19/

All mass event attendees must be fully vaccinated; those who are unvaccinated must have proof of full COVID-19 recovery within the past 90 days. Mass events can now go ahead under strict restrictions. Events have been categorised into low, medium and high risk:  - Low risk: capacity of 100 or 50% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks, food and drinks are prohibited, sitting is mandatory, and event takes place without singing, encouragement or other loud vocal expressions.  - Medium risk: capacity of 100 or 25% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks and here is a fixed sitting or standing arrangement.   - High risk: capacity of 20 people. Defined as events in a public catering operation or a non-low-risk mass event and a medium-risk mass event; this includes weddings, parties and other celebrations.   Funerals are exempt from these restrictions, as are meetings of public authorities, elections, and mass events necessary for the course of the following professional competitions in selected sports.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220123200410/https://korona.gov.sk/obmedzenia-pre-hromadne-podujatia/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220123195717/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4988%3Ainformacia-k-novym-vyhlakam-uvz-sr-respiratory-hromadne-podujatia-prevadzky-otp-na-pracoviskach&catid=56%3Atlaove-spravy&Itemid=62

Everyone aged over 12 years and 2 months arriving from all countries by all means of transport must register in advance of travel by completing the âeHranicaâ form on the Slovak governmentâs website. Fully vaccinated and recently recovered travellers do not need to quarantine but must carry proof of vaccination or recovery. Unvaccinated travellers must either self-quarantine for 5 days and then quarantine ends as long as they remain asymptomatic; OR travellers may take a PCR test at any time after entry and self-isolation will end upon receipt of the negative results.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220205133911/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220205134008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/entry-requirements

https://archive.vn/CEfdD  Ending of most Covid restrictions -  no more testing (rapid antigen or PCR) in schools)   face masks still required in school  Advise that symptomatic persons should stay home

https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1643.0-1647.108  The organisation of public cultural events in open public spaces is not permitted, but it is permitted in enclosed public spaces with fixed seating, whereby every other seat must be left vacant, the use of face masks is mandatory, and all participants must comply with the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule.    Public cultural events may only be held on condition that the performers and people involved in the organisation of the event that have direct contact with visitors meet the requirements of the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule. This condition does not apply to persons under the age of 12. The public cultural event can be attended by a maximum of 750 visitors.

14 December 2021 - Vaccination of children aged 5 to 11 could start in Slovenia today as the advisory group on immunization at the National Institute of Public Health (NIJZ) approved a proposal by paediatricians to recommend Covid-19 vaccination for children last evening.    Cannot find a source for when over 12's were made eligible so coding from this date until further information available    http://web.archive.org/web/20220203152012/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/9344-covid-19-vaccination-starts-for-children-aged-5-11-in-slovenia

9th Feb 2022, Sweden scrapped almost all of its few pandemic restrictions on Wednesday and stopped most testing for COVID-19, even as the pressure on the healthcare systems remained high and some scientists begged for more patience in fighting the disease.    Advice and recommendations  - Get vaccinated if you can  The Swedish Public Health Agency recommends that everyone aged 12 and older be vaccinated against covid-19. It reduces the risk of serious illness and death.    - Stay home if you have symptoms  Anyone with symptoms of Covid-19 should stay at home and  avoid close contacts with others if you are ill with symptoms of Covid-19.    - Special advice to those not vaccinated  Not being vaccinated increases the risk of serious illness from Covid-19. To avoid becoming infected, people who are unvaccinated should be extra careful and avoid crowded indoor environments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115741/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210135400/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/sweden-declare-pandemic-over-despite-warnings-scientists-2022-02-09/

According to the Ministry, the COVID-19 measures will be lifted in two stages. The restrictions of the first stage will be lifted on February 9, whereas the second stage is due to begin on April 1.    In the first stage, Sweden will lift the requirement to present a vaccination certificate when entering different venues, including public events, bars, restaurants, shopping centres, and public transport.    This means that travellers and citizens of the country will be permitted restriction-free entry to the majority of places starting from February 9.    Other restrictions will also be lifted next week. Public gathering, eating and drinking establishments, and shopping centres will no longer have a limit of persons allowed in one area at the same time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205070451/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/sweden-to-lift-majority-of-covid-19-restriction-on-february-9/

To avoid becoming infected, people who are unvaccinated should be extra careful and avoid crowded indoor environments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115741/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210135400/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/sweden-declare-pandemic-over-despite-warnings-scientists-2022-02-09/

According to the Ministry, the COVID-19 measures will be lifted in two stages. The restrictions of the first stage will be lifted on February 9, whereas the second stage is due to begin on April 1.    In the first stage, Sweden will lift the requirement to present a vaccination certificate when entering different venues, including public events, bars, restaurants, shopping centres, and public transport.    This means that travellers and citizens of the country will be permitted restriction-free entry to the majority of places starting from February 9.    Other restrictions will also be lifted next week. Public gathering, eating and drinking establishments, and shopping centres will no longer have a limit of persons allowed in one area at the same time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205070451/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/sweden-to-lift-majority-of-covid-19-restriction-on-february-9/

9th Feb 2022, Sweden scrapped almost all of its few pandemic restrictions on Wednesday and stopped most testing for COVID-19, even as the pressure on the healthcare systems remained high and some scientists begged for more patience in fighting the disease.    Advice and recommendations  - Get vaccinated if you can  The Swedish Public Health Agency recommends that everyone aged 12 and older be vaccinated against covid-19. It reduces the risk of serious illness and death.    - Stay home if you have symptoms  Anyone with symptoms of Covid-19 should stay at home and  avoid close contacts with others if you are ill with symptoms of Covid-19.    - Special advice to those not vaccinated  Not being vaccinated increases the risk of serious illness from Covid-19. To avoid becoming infected, people who are unvaccinated should be extra careful and avoid crowded indoor environments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115741/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210135400/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/sweden-declare-pandemic-over-despite-warnings-scientists-2022-02-09/

9th Feb 2022, there is a ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU/EEA. This ban applies to foreign nationals and remains in effect until 31 March 2022. There are a number of exemptions to the ban based on work or studies, family connections or urgent family reasons, as well as a number of countries whose residents are exempted.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220131153810/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

A ban on entry to Sweden is in effect for non-essential travel from most countries outside the EU/EEA. The ban does not apply to Swedish citizens, citizens of another EU/EEA country or citizens from a number of exempt countries. Swedish citizens and foreign nationals who are registered in Sweden are always entitled to travel into Sweden.    Read more under International travel, where you will find information about which countries are exempt from the entry ban and what is needed in order to be granted an exemption from the entry ban.     Foreign nationals travelling to Sweden from countries outside EU/EEA must be exempted from the travel ban and show evidence of a negative test of Covid-19, from within the past 72 hours.    There is from 9 February 2022 no longer an entry ban from an EU/EEA country, but from the rest of the world the entry ban is in effect till 31 March 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222101403/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Yes     Which vaccines are available in TAJIKISTAN?    The U.S. Embassy in Dushanbe is aware that Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Sputnik V and Sinovac-CoronaVac  COVID-19 vaccines are available at Prospekt Medical Clinic (48-702-44-00), subject to availability. Please contact the clinic directly for information about cost and availability.  The quality of Tajikistanâs medical infrastructure is significantly below Western standards, with shortages of basic medical supplies, including disposable needles, anesthetics, and antibiotics.  Due to extremely limited vaccine availability, we strongly recommend that travelers complete their COVID-19 vaccination before traveling to Tajikistan.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211227070129/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

You will need to complete the online form (Form for Entry to Turkey), a maximum of 72 hours before travelling, to enter Turkey if aged 6 and over. This is not necessary for transit passengers. All arrivals into Turkey will be subject to a medical evaluation for symptoms of coronavirus, including temperature checks. Arrivals may be subject to random PCR testing on arrival. If youâre fully vaccinated, you can enter Turkey without needing to test or quarantine. At least 14 days must have passed since your second dose of the vaccine and the vaccine must be approved by the Turkish Ministry of Health or World Health Organization. You must present proof that you have been fully vaccinated to enter Turkey. If youâre not fully vaccinated, youâll need to show proof of a negative PCR test (taken no more than 72 hours before entry), rapid antigen test (taken no more than 48 hours before entry), or proof of a recent recovery from COVID-19 within the last six months, when entering Turkey.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220221211338/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkey/entry-requirements
